ReviewList.Text: I first read about this book a few months ago.  While I am a fan of Stephen King, I'm not a huge fan.  I don't typically buy his books the day they are released, but when I read the premise for this one I just thought that it was a really neat idea and I couldn't wait for it to be released so that I could read it.  Then I got a little nervous about it.  From the time I read the teaser I thought that there were so many interesting directions that someone could take this story, but what if it tanks?  That's always the pitfall of a really neat idea...  what if it fails to really bloom like you think it could?  But this is Stephen King.  For my review, I'd like to establish that I was born almost 7 years after JFK died.  I am not a JFK scholar and I did not read this book trying to hyper-analyze the historical accuracy of the book.  I took it as a fictional exploration of a historical event produced not to answer any historical questions but just to entertain and provoke thought.  I feel it was very successful on both points.  My fears that Stephen King was going to take a great idea and go nowhere with it were definitely unfounded.  He also works in all his usual Stephen King "givens"...  the story starts in Maine.  We even get to "visit" a couple of characters from other Stephen King books and the town of Derry, though the majority of the book is set in Texas of course.  On the whole I usually review books based on how well spent I feel my time was in reading it and I am in no way disappointed in this one.  If you buy the book I hope you enjoy it as much as I did and thank you for taking the time to read my review.

When I first started the book I could not put it down. I cried a lot from certain events and a weapon that I didn't expect. I got through a 1/3 of the book in a couple of days. When I got to the middle of the book, I felt it really got dragged out.  I understood why the book was written the way it was. It was like reading a journal. The stalking of Oswald was driving me insane.It was overkill in my opinion. I felt after 200 pages I got it, your stalking him. This caused me to feel detached from certain secondary characters deaths or injuries.I just wanted the book to go to the next level. I was very pleased with the end of the book. Once you get to April of 1963 the book goes back to a nail bitting page turner. The ending had a sweet touch. I wished the emotional impact from the beginiing and ending were in the middle as well.

No spoliers! Okay. As some others have written, the book has a wonderful, grabber opening. I was taken in by the premise. But, the entire middle section of the book is tedious. Simply, this book should have been 300 pages and not the 800+ that was written. (Amazingly, this is my first Stephen King book, and will probably be my last.) I am stunned by the five and four star review. I just found myself skimming over the entire middle portion of the book. I was curious about the ending so, I gathered my courage, and plodded on. I just could not endure the detail, upon unnecessary detail. (I have refrained from the details of the middle portion to avoid spoliers.) Take book out of the library or borrow a copy. Great premise ruined by the author's desire to overwhelm us with the past and the details of an interetsing time traveller.

I think it has been years since I have been able to get through a King book. I've thought of his recent efforts as a sad decline in quality.  I was a huge fan of his earlier work, his collections of short stories, The Stand, IT etc.  But in the past five years I've pretty much felt that he has lost it.  This book, however, is wonderful.  Does the actual writing compare to his earlier efforts? In my opinion, no, but it doesn't matter.  This is still the King of old, a book you do not want to put down, even if you have to stay up all night to read it.  It isn't the masterpiece that I felt The Stand was, nor as beautifully written as some of his older short story collections, but there is much to love in this newest effort.  It is a satisfying ride, and you are sad when it ends.

I listened to this on Audiobook. It was amazing. I would get home from work and sit in my car just to keep listening. I don't know how to explain how great this book was. I literally feel like a chapter in my life is over now that I'm finished with it. You feel SO close to the characters and they are so well developed you hurt with them, laugh with them, cry often and feel every moment as the minutes count down to the climax of the book. It is amazing. By far the BEST Stephen King book I have EVER read. I don't know how he will follow this one up. I have never been a big Stephen King fan, but this book has literally changed my life. It is amazing. Good luck stopping because you eat, breathe, sleep, walk, work, etc. George Amberson/Jake Epping.

Those are the opening words to Stephen King's 11/22/63.  A description of the main character Jake Epping, and rather accurate one of myself too.  But I'll tell you what, I was a crying man by the end of this book.  I'm not going to give away too much or write a long winded review...but listen to what most of the people are saying.  This is one of, possibly THE best, King stories you'll read.

I really enjoyed this book. I could'nt put it down once I started reading it. I always liked stories of time travel and this one is great.At the very heart of this book, it is a love story, through and through. The time travel is just the means of telling a fantastic love story. The last chapter of the book made me feel so sorry for the charcter, but oh what an ending. It isn't very often that a book grabs you and makes you feel that way. I have'nt read all of Kings work, but of all the ones that I have read, this is now my favorite.

This book received an incredible amount of praise from critics and readers.  The plot is indeed intriguing and promising.  Man goes back to before JFK was killed an attempts to prevent the assassination.  The beginning of this book and most of the end are excellent.  Full of action, suspense, and surprises.  The problem is the extremely long middle of the novel - the bridge between the setup and the conclusion.  There is simply not enough of interest going on.  There are some cute scenes and ideas (creating buzz words long before their time) but this part simply drags.  This might have been a great short story of even a novella.  So because of the problems with the middle section, even thought I basically enjoyed the book, I will not be recommending it to my friends.

The notion of time rifts in the form of small "bubbles" was a facinating premise and King's prose is, as always absorbing.  But I expected much more from this book.  Over 3/4ths of it, I'd say, was a lead up to that fateful day followed by an all too brief aftermath and wrap up.  Seriously.  We spend page after page and chapter after chapter in this quiet little Texas town, endearing ourselves to rather ordinary characters.  That and watching our hero stalk Oswald around Dallas/Ft Worth.  Then, when we finally get to the part we've all been waiting for, poof.  It's over.  Of course we boomers have been wondering all our lives how things would have been different if Kennedy had lived.  How would the civil rights struggle evolved? Would Kennedy have been re-elected? Would he have escalated the conflicts in SE Asia? What about the Great Society, would anything like it have been pushed through without LBJ's arm-twisting from the oval office?  Women's reproductive rights?  Would the moral majority have sprung up and pulled the republican party so far right?  Would our path with Kennedy have veered away from these and other social currents and if so, where might it have taken us?  King gives us a bare glimpse at what we came for, a very brief passage and then the book is over, aside from an highly sentimental closing tug at the heartstrings. I wish he's given us more.

To begin, I must admit that I usually love Stephen King's books, so I assumed I would like this one. However, I quickly discovered that this was very different from his previous novels. It reads almost a bit like historical fiction with a hint of King's supernatural and spooky style. I absolutely loved this book and found it difficult to put it down. When I wasn't reading it, I was thinking about it. As usually, I found myself astounded by King's creativity and originality. I cannot recommend this book enough, and it's important to note that for those who are not fans of Stephen King, put that aside and read this book anyway. I think you will be most pleasantly surprised!

Wasn't sure how I'd react or appreciate this one. Loved Under the Dome and much of King's previous work...but this novel, I feared, being based on historical fact, left me feeling a bit apprehensive. The beginning of the book, while interesting, seemed a bit slow. However, the last 200 pages are beyond a thrill ride! All said, this book has stayed with me for several days...and I think it will stay with me for many more days to come. Don't want to give too much away...but the ending is very satisfying and left a tear in my eye. However, the editors missed one huge glaring error: On page 781, Jackie Kennedy refers to her two young children, and Jake remembers them as Carolyn and John. How King's editors missed the fact that "Carolyn" is really Caroline is beyond me!!! HUGE error! For those of us who lived through the assassination and its aftermath, this is a marvelous "what if" tale. One of King's best.

As most others who bother writing reviews of King's books, I am a huge fan and have absolutely LOVED his other works. 11-22-63 left me longing for more. It was a nice story, but WAY TOO LONG. This story could have been told in 200-300 pages tops! If you read it, brace yourself for about 500 pages of build-up only to be somewhat let down at the conclusion.

I'll make this short, because its 1:00 a.m., and I just finished the book. This book is a massive 850 pages: The first third of the book was classic King, with an ensemble small down caste and fairly rapid action. The middle third was fairly slow going, spending alot of time on character development, but still managed to make me feel engrossed with the story. The final third I wont give away, only to say that you'll almost surely feel emotionally attached to the conclusion. Overall, I'd place it not in the top 5 of kings books, but possibly in the top 10.

Ever since I saw a dog mutilate himself,a car possessed and a spider in a sewer(clowns I'm ok with), I have figured I could write off King as a reader. Now I have to rethink a big library trip. I am going to have to start at the beginning.  This story took me to many places on my mind. Stories that my mom told about how the country felt about Kennedy who was killed while she was pregnant with me. Tales of segregation but even she never saw the plank horror. I have been reading this the last few days as the summer '12 Olympics are on.  I swear I win a gold medal for speed reading during the countdosn minutes nearing the assisination time. Mr King, with tears on my eyes since I just finished your tale,wear you crown well!  Thank you'

I am on my third "listening" of this book.  The reader is incredible.  The main character is "all of us".  As much as I have loved Stephen King over the years, his recent books have left me unhappy and dissatisfied.  This one has the depth and ending that will make one satisfied...and still with a bit of wonder. As in The Dark Tower (and other novels), we are in Stephen King's world.  We see characters who we have previously met.  We are alerted to "19".  We go back to a world which we have been in and enjoyed.  I loved it!  Hopefully, eventually, I will move on to other audio books I have purchased, but right now I just "keep listening" AGAIN! I can't seem to leave.  Maybe I need to go back to the Dark Tower just to "leave for a bit." Even my sister-in-law, who would never read Stephen King was entralled.  Try it.  You will not be disappointed.

I could not put this book down. It's not so much the suspense as it is the story telling. For several days after finishing the book I mourned the loss of my friends Sadie and George. King brings characters to life so well you feel like they are your personal friends, so when I finished the book I lost touch with them. It really was like having close friends move away.

I haven't read a King novel in twenty years or more, though he was my favorite writer when I was a young teen.  As I got older and became more exposed to real brutality and horror in our world, I got more and more sensitive to reading fictionalized stories that contain graphic violence and disturbing scenes.  I have run out of things to read and saw the great reviews and thought, what the heck, I'll give it a shot.  Maybe I've just outgrown King, but I found this book to be very formulaic, predictable, well-crafted but not great.  I didn't like the protagonist's narrative voice.  I don't ever want to hear the word "obdurate" (the reference to the past as "obdurate" is made 25 plus times, and reference to the past "harmonizing with itself" was made as many times or more).  Toward the end I started wondering if it was really King who wrote this novel, or the writer who wrote "Shades of Gray".  Only this wasn't porn, it was just overuse of the same words, over and over and over again.  And the word "obdurate" is not a word that you hear in everyday language, so its overuse jumps out at you throughout the novel, I also thought the book started really dragging halfway through.  The last several chapters were painful to read.  There was the "It's a Wonderful Life" scene toward the end when the protagonist runs through the town (only the town is different, because of changes made to the obdurate past).  There was the predictable ending, better when Ray Bradbury did it.  This will be my last attempt to read a King novel.  Not gory or graphic, just plain bad.

When I first heard the concept of Stephen King's new novel, I was skeptical. The idea of someone finding a way to travel back through time and stop the Kennedy assassination seemed like something far more generic and B-movie-esque than I hoped for from King. But, hey, it's King, so of course I'll try it...and I wasn't ten pages in before my doubts started to fade. One of the things I forgot in my expectations is how well King can make even the oddest scenario seem both logical and yet completely fresh, and his handling of the time-travel method here is both, creating something that feels like no other time travel story I've ever heard in my life, yet one that feels...well, natural in a way you might not expect. But more than that, 11/22/63 is a testament to King's storytelling skills: this thing moves like a rocket, and there are scattered climaxes and scenes that pack such impact that I had to take a break afterward. King puts on a clinic with regard to pacing, structuring his story deftly and juggling dozens of characters so well that it looks effortless - only to collide them in ways you're never prepared for. It's those characters, of course, that really carry the book - you'd expect nothing less from King, whose character work is always second to none, but his cast of characters here is something special, something far more touching and complex than I might have expected. Maybe it's because for King, the past isn't a gimmick - it's a vibrant, fully-realized place, one that's as much a character as any of the people that inhabit it. There's so much more here to rave about, and so little space, so let me just say this: for my money, 11/22/63 is probably King's best book since the accident, and even one of his best, period. It's ambitious, profound, intense, unsettling, moving, and powerful, and it's the work of a master at the peak of his craft.

I'll start off by saying this was my first Stephen King novel, but I plan on reading more from him.  I was initially skeptical of this book since it appeared that most of the reviews were from people born in the baby-boomer era.  Clearly, these readers have ties to this book and the Kennedy incident.  However, I wanted to give it a shot and I found it to be both a good read and informative.  I learned a lot and the novel made me wish I could take a time machine back to the 60s!  King does a great job making the reader feel connected to the characters (the 850 pages didn't hurt either).  I found myself rooting for George/Jake and intrigued to see what life would be like if Kennedy survived.  I would actually give this novel 3.5 stars but I had to choose 3 or 4 so I went 4.  My only thing is I wish King would have given us more on the aftermath and about 150 pages could have been cut.  Other then that, great book!  I hear a movie is in the works and I am looking forward to it!

I loved 11/22/63 right from the beginning and couldn't put my kindle down! Reading this book makes you question yourself "Would I go back in time to change history? and could I deal with the ramifications of that change?"  Everything happens for a reason and only God knows those reasons.  Our lives ebb and flow with every cause having an effect.  This book helps you to see that even in a tragedy, later down the road good may come from that tragedy.  We just never know.....

Wow, 5+ stars for sure! What an exquisite time I had throughout this story. I love the way King gently pulled me into the past and made the world he described not only real and believable, but filled with characters I both adored and hated. The interweaving of this tale through other stories in the SK universe was cool as well. Plus, the haunting presence of the obdurate past hanging over every page provided a level of tension I couldn't shake till the last page. I thought the ending was perfect, and even though I was left with a sense of foreboding and loss, I still honestly feel that the ending was true to the story.
An engaging interweaving of two of my favorite fascinations, the Kennedy assassination and Stephen King.  Don't think I turned on my TV for a week.  Greatly enjoyed it from cover to cover.

If you want to travel back in time to the early 1960s to read about some guy being swept off his feet at a high school in Texas, read this book. However, if you're looking for a fantastical, imaginative look from America's foremost science fiction writer at what might have happened if someone had been able to go back in time to Nov. 22, 1963 and alter American history, you've come to the wrong place. Really, Mr. King? Really? I read all those pages and my payoff was a last-minute race up the stairs of the TSBD? If I wanted to read a love story I'd read the latest from Lavenia Kent. Who??? Exactly. Do better.

I finished 11/22/63 about two weeks ago and was extremely happy with my purchase and time well spent.  While I was listening to Glen Miller's "In the Mood" (a reoccurring reference throughout the novel) recently, it illuminated scenes and memories from a book that I feel as though has afflicted me with happiness and melancholy.  The love story that arises from the main character and a librarian in the past is evocative writing and the suspense that slowly builds throughout the novel boils to a dramatic conclusion.  With an ending that I appreciated very much so and with storytelling that is performed masterfully, I cannot recommend this novel enough.  There is a clear reason why this book has garnered 500+ positive reviews since its release last month -- 11/22/63 is a treat, a delight, and a novel that deserves your reading crave.

As are many Americans, I've always taken an interest in the events surrounding the Kennedy assassination. Not a fascination, and I'm not a conspiracy theorist, but it is compelling. When I saw the 'what if' prospect surrounding one of the darkest days in American history, and then saw it was Steven King, I was on board for the ride. And I absolutely loved it. The characters are endearing, the eras vivid in my mind's eye, and the plot well crafted and engrossing. My only wish would be that King would have written this with more focus on what happened after the foiled attempt - I went into it with that mindset. That said, it was still a fantastic tale, and a great page turner. You won't be disappointed.

This SK book could have been much shorter.....I found myself speed reading thru many pages. It certainly was well researched, giving the reader a good glimpse of life in the late fifties early 60's but the contradictions, while unavoidable, were glaring. I remember reading The Shining way back when and feeling the terror at the Overlook Hotel and the pure evil I felt with The Stand. What I consider to be SK's signature books. There was none of that with 11/23. It was, well, a good read but not what I was hoping for.

I don't think I've ever written a book review in all my years buying and reading books from Amazon.  (I HAVE reviewed a few products, though.)  However, this novel inspired me to write one as it's nothing short of amazing.  When I was a kid, I'd devour Stephen King's earlier novels such as Carrie, The Stand, The Shining, etc.  I ended up growing out of that "horror"/supernatural genre and moved on to what I thought at the time was more "quality" fiction.  Let me tell you, though... Mr. King has a resurrected (so to speak) fan in me with this novel.  I won't re-tell the story because others here have done that very well, but I do believe this is his best work ever and probably the best novel I've read in years. The characters are so real you can reach out and touch them (and you simply can't help but fall in love with Jake, a.k.a. George).  Not to mention that the pacing, the momentum, the suspense of this book are crafted brilliantly.  Whether you were "alive" or even aware when JFK was assassinated or not, this story will have you mesmerized.  I absolutely LOVED it!

This book has some long, saggy subplots. I was enchanted by the visit to 1958, but we didn't get to experience much of that. THere were a few cultural icons that took me back, but not nearly enough to evoke the era. Instead, we are plunged into a seedy romance between characters without much spark. All we know about Sadie is that she is a chain smoker and is clumbsy... not enough depth to register any empathy. I, too, did research on the Kennedy assasination, and reached a very different conclusion than King has. That is forgivable, but the first 75% of the book was too slow moving, took me where I did not want to go, and bored me with paper thin characters. I endured to see how he would end it (and King fans endure the detours, we are used to them but hope they won't dilute the plot too much). The detour turned out to be the main story. The last 15% of the book is engaging though, and salvaged the whole story from being a huge flop in my opinion. It seems to be written for the big screen, using the lure of big screen sex and not much else.

An enthralling book, full of surprises - not least the fact that by the end, one cares less about whether or not JFK's assassination is thwarted, than about the relationships between the fictional characters, and especially between the hero and the woman he's fallen for. Some reviewers are calling King the American Dickens and the case for that description is just getting stronger and stronger. As with Dickens, there are occasional slips (I find it hard to believe that anyone in 1960 said 'You rock!', and I laughed at the reference to a 'gorgeous man's wallet' - is that a gorgeous wallet designed for a man, or a wallet belonging to a gorgeous man? :) -- well, even Homer nods). But the book is a masterpiece by a novelist at the very top of his form...noble, heroic, eloquent.

Let me begin by saying that I have not read all of King's work.  I have not read The Stand (I actually just bought it to start reading -I mention The Stand because I see great reviews on it, but I can't compare this book to it since I haven't read it).  I have read a lot of his books though, and this one is my favorite so far.  While reading this book, I actually felt like I was with the main character on his journey.  I'm trying to be careful not to give anything away, so my review may not be as helpful as you'd like.  I can try to tell you what my taste is: I like Stephen King, John Grisham, and I liked the Harry Potter books.  (I also really liked the LOST television series).  I spent just about every free minute of this past weekend reading 11/22/63 and even though I really wanted to know what happened at the end, I was kind of sad when it was over. My sister had given me a book that she had by Mary Higgins Clark, but (forgive me if you are a fan)after reading 11/22/63, I have been forcing myself to read her book the past two nights and I found it to be boring in comparison (again, only my opinion so please don't take offense if you like her work).  I gave up on that and just went ahead and bought The Stand. 11/22/63 was probably my favorite book ever by any author.  Also, Stephen King said that the part of the book regarding the details of the assasination are based on facts; he did a lot of research to write the book.

This is my first Stephen King book.  I don't care for horror and gore, so I've never considered his books as something I would read.  But the subject of this one grabbed my attention.  When the Kindle price dropped, I got it.  This book is by far in the top 2 of books I've read in my life and I'm 57! Stephen King is brilliant.  I was drawn in from the first page.  This book has it all.  If you're in my age group, it reminds you of things long forgotten. There's history, mystery, Sci-Fi, and romance with each element having the power to trip over the others. Don't think you'll know how it turns out because you won't.  The end was quite literally in the last sentence.  somewhere in the middle of the book, my mind was exhausted, so I stopped to read something mindless, then went back to it.  When I finished it, I didn't start another book for days.  It haunted me and haunts me still.  You will ask yourself, "what if I had done something else?  where would my life be today?"  When a book has the power to entertain, think, question, and linger after the last word is read, you've got yourself a book!

I have listened to audio books for over 10 years.  During that time I estimate that I have listened to more than 400 books.  I have never cared for Stephn King's books based on what I have read about the subject matter of each book.  As best I can recall, this is the first Stephen King book that I have done. However, this book intrigued me & I rate it among the best I have ever listened to.  I thought that it might dwell too much on the assanation of JFK but much to my surprise, only about 25% of the book was actually about 11/22/63, although it was alluded to throughout the book.  The rest of the book was extremely interesting & I highly recommended it to those of you that may have lived through the late 50's & early60's & enjoy some of the nostalgia of that time.

fun science fiction book about traveling through a fissure in time from the present to 1958--in hopes of stopping the JFK assassination on 11/22/63. without giving away the book--its seems like a cross between the old show "quantum leap" and the movie "back to the future" with a love story nicely interwoven in between by king. king develops the two central characters--george and sadie--nicely and uses a good pace with his writing. the book reads pretty quickly. a fun book to read.

With the publication of 11/22/63, Master SK has done something that I was doubtful would ever happen again. He has overwhelmingly silenced his critics, written a brilliant novel of depth and believability and created a work that slides effortlessly into the high five of his canon. Arguably, this is King's most poignant and human book to date. If you can buy the premise of a time portal residing in the corner of a greasy diner, the rest of the book is as palatable as anything the horror meister has ever written. For those who pay attention to foreshadowing, there are no surprise endings here. As King reminded us dozens of times, "The past is obdurate." Perceptive readers will grasp very early what that means, but the beauty of this book is that it is so exceptionally developed and craftily constructed, that most of them just won't care. The motivation to read is encapsulated in the unfolding of the story. The journey is the reward, and I submit to you that it is one of the best journeys of recent years. Jake is the most unlikely hero imaginable: teacher, dullard, milquetoast. He embodies a certain everyman quality that all people can relate to, whether through personal reflection or acquaintance. His development is remarkable, made all the more so by actions that ring soundly of real-life decision making. He becomes what any of us might have, given the circumstances. Sadie is a grounded cornerstone of humanity and stability in the face of Jake's shaky and uncertain arc. She is one of the finest female characters King has ever written. As to other players from small-town barkeeps to no-town property owners to big-city reds, the supporting characters are almost all excellently rendered. I won't ruin it for those who have yet to read, but long-time King fans will be treated to Easter eggs that make you feel like you're in a special inner circle of author confidence. (wink, wink) In a time travel novel, the most critical element, and the trickiest to get right, is the conclusion. Too often, the reader is left with a bitter taste of disappointment. There are few other genre niches that are as rewarding to read about and as depressing to conclude as time travel. You will have no such issue here. I can say with certainty that this book ended exactly as it should have and that isn't to say that it ends the way I wanted it to. There is a moment in the last few pages that is as emotionally piquant as any SK has written and will live in my book memory for the rest of my life. Like it's characters, this book transcends time and space. I would not be surprised if 100-years hence, this novel is the one that has bibliophiles still applauding the name King.

I like long books - I hate it when they end too soon!  I LOVED this book.  Who cares if it could have been shorter - it entertained me all the way through.  Add this to my list of fave King books (along with Under the Dome, The Stand, and the Longest Walk).  Well worth the read!

This book took me way longer than it should have to read due to school and other projects but I'm glad I finally found the motivation to finish it. Time travel is always a touchy subject but this book didn't confuse me at all. Even the string theory at the end was understandable. I'm a sucker for conspiracy theories so this was fantastic. Though some was obviously fiction, the subject was compelling and changed my perspective and beliefs a lot. The romance was such a great touch to this story as well. Sadie and Jake (George) really made me happy and even though most guys aren't into romantic books, this one didn't over-do it. The first person narrative was awesome as well. I could put myself in those situations and I really felt like I was following the character through every page of this book. The parallels (aka "Harmonies") in this book are also fun to point out and notice. It's intense, fun, suspenseful, hilarious, and so much more. I've only read 3 of King's novels, including this one, and I have to say, it may be his best. I can't see how he can top it. The subject matter was so interesting and his opinions were excellent. I paid attention to every detail and reading this book was a total blast. I definitely recommend this book to fans of time traveling, romance, the late 50's and early 60's, humor, and first-person narratives. It was so incredible and I'm sad it's over. Please read this book. It should get more credit than it's been given.

I'm not sure what I can add that other readers have not already commented on, but here goes. The premise is good. There are a lot of holes in the story if you look carefully- probably could have been taken care of with a thorough editing.  One minor but typical example would be Al's purchasing of an entire day's worth of meat for his restaurant back in 1958 and bringing it back to the present...in one trip and completely by hand. Granted, time-travel is hard to swallow, but at least get the details to be believable.  It's hard to believe Al would be able to purchase a day's worth of meat and haul it up the stairs back into the present. Or why Al trusts Jake so much to reveal the secret of the bubble to Jake only, and why he is so obsessed with changing history.I think that the book could have been trimmed by a couple hundred pages and probably not lost any luster. I'll try and stay spoiler-free, but the first event in the past Jake changes (in Derry) reads great, as does his relationship with Sadie. The Oswald stuff got very repetitive and monotonous until the very end, which was engrossing. I liked the glimpse into the "what-if" scenario after Jake changes history. Perhaps what I liked best though, was the ending, which was pretty endearing and just a little sad.

I just finished reading "11/22/63" and could not put it down! I was a big fan of King 20 years ago and read almost all of his books published in the 80's and 90's. However, in my opinion, after awhile reading his books became a chore and I had to stop reading him. After I saw him on the "Today" show last week, I was intrigued. So, I bought the Kindle edition and started reading. I was captivated by his main character, Jake, who is a very cerebral guy. He finds it so hard to believe in the ability to go back in time. When he finally agrees to go back to 1958 and try to prevent the Kennedy assasination, we follow along with all Jake's misgivings about what he's trying to do and why. When he falls in love with Sadie, I really hoped that they would be able to return to 2011 together. Although King did not end the book with a classical love story ending, I felt King's ending was very satisfying. I would implore any former King fans to BUY THIS BOOK. It's fantastic!!

The premise of this book was very intriguing, and I was really hoping that King would do it justice. Sadly he drops the ball by making the novel painfully long, full of sappy, poorly-written romance and unrealistic relationships instead of an interesting exploration of American history in the fifties and sixties. When King is in his wheelhouse building tension and providing flash moments of fear, he is excellent. However, when he lingers too long on relationships he is out of his element. There is very little of the former and much of the latter. King's folksy, corny dialogue is very unnatural and often sounds like it was written by a high school student. He could have overcome this weakness by examining in more depth what it would be like for a person to have the opportunity to witness famous figures and events from the past and learn about the lives of older family members and friends. Instead, the cloying, uninspired love story takes precedence, making the book feel like little more than a wasted opportunity. There are some moments of intrigue, and I did feel that I learned more about the people and events surrounding the Kennedy assassination. Beyond that, reading 11/22/63 felt like time poorly spent. For King fans only.

Another fabulous work by Stephen King. Up until "Under the Dome," I thought he was losing his magic. But since that one he hasn't missed, and he sure didn't miss with this book, any more than Oswald missed with his weapon on that Friday in Dallas. Paranoia is an old theme with King--in "The Stand," it was the military and our national government. In "Under the Dome," local government and law enforcement ran amuck. But now King has had a thought only he could even think--that a world with a living JFK could turn out worse than the screwed-up mess we live in today. Reading the book in audio form, as I did, added an entirely different dimension. The narrator, when speaking naturally, sounded for all the world like Sam Kinison. As the tale unfolded, he invented voices for the characters, and did excellent impression of famous voices who appeared in the book-Chet Huntley, David Brinkley, Walter Cronkite, and of course the man of the hour, JFK himself. What some dismiss as "fluff," I thought really carried this story, and carried me along-the life Jake built with Sadie, Jake cooling his heels all those years waiting for that one day, then finding out it had all been a colossal bust. What a long strange trip this one was.

I actually got this book from the library and was not expecting it to be over 800 pages.  As a short loan, I thought for sure I'd have to stop halfway through and re-request it to finish it up later.  I actually got through the whole novel in 8 days, it was that good.  Yes, it's long, but unlike other longer novels I've read, it didn't seem to drag or have unimportant events in it that (had I been his editor) I would've taken out.  King is obviously a skilled writer, having been doing it for about as long as I've been alive, but I was still entranced by his characters and found myself wrapped up in the story.  When Jake runs into problems getting history to change, or running into problem after problem, I was on the edge of my seat.  I was rooting for him to get there and stop Oswald.  History is obdurate- that's the theme throughout the book.  Along the way, you'll meet many different characters who will touch your heart, make you smile, and keep you rooting for the good guys.  And there's even a little love story in there, for those who are closet romantics like myself.

This is one of the best books I have read in recent memory. The only bad thing about it was that it ended! The story is all-encompassing, and I put my life on hold to finish the book. I am 80s baby, but I still loved the depiction of the years 1958 to 1963. I really felt as though I was living in the story. The setting was painted perfectly and the characters felt so real. It was an extremely well-written book and the character development was out of this world. I am not a regular Stephen King reader by any stretch (the only other King novel I've read is Duma Key - another book I very much enjoyed), but this is a great book. Period. Whether it is outside his genre, it is an intriguing story that sucks you in. I did not guess the ending, however, it was in line with the rest of the book and I think the most perfect ending that he could have chosen. I would highly recommend this book to anyone looking for an excellent read. Beware that it might take over your life until you finish!!!

Have been a Stephen King fan for a long time and this book was on the top of my list. Makes you sit back and wonder what life would be like if you went back in time and changed even just one thing. Brings all the "what ifs" out in the open. I listened to it in unabridged audio form and now I want to purchase the hardback so I may go back and highlight certain passages. It was Stephen King at his best.

Take a deep breath and leap down the 'Rabbit Hole' into the Past!  Thrilling and convincing! Although I didn't exist during that era, my mind's eye realized many of the staples of mid-century America as they came to life once more. The tinny, lilting pop music of the AM radios! The bright red Vendo machines chilling glass Co'Cola bottles! The ridiculously bulky and aerodynamically-challenged autos!  My palate yearned for that rich and frothy rootbeer that Jake-George Amberson-Epping had the fortune of dumping down his yap! Seriously though, I was quite surprised when, after delving into this novel because of the JFK content, I became even more engrossed in the lives of the rest of the characters! This book transports the reader and evokes some intense emotions along the way. The factual elements relating to the Assassination are accurate enough to ensure epic status IMO! AND YES, OSWALD DID IT ALONE!! Poo-Poo on the conspiracy-theorists!

I have been a King fan since the first book. It's hard to pick a favorite but it would be between, The Shining, It, The Stand, The Talisman or The Dark Tower series. A lot of old time fans have given this one a bad review but I just finished it and must say it is an extremely well written book. Many have said he is too big for his britches now and needs to be edited, that the book is too long by half. I disagree. While it is more of a main stream novel than those I earlier mentioned, it is to me an instant classic. I learned a few years ago with movies and books that I could ruin them merely through my own expectations. I've gone back and reread books that I didn't like, this time with an open mind and no expectations, and have thoroughly enjoyed them the second time. After reading many of the poor reviews by long time fans I decided to read it anyway with no expectations and fell in love with this book.  GREAT JOB STEPHEN!!!

Couldn't put this one down - SK's best since Duma Key ! And it surpasses that book by painting such an accurate picture of what life was like in the late 50s-early 60s you can practically taste the non-preservative laden food , smell the hair pomade , cigarette smoke , and exhaust from the vintage automobiles . One of King's best qualities has always been his meticulous descriptive powers and here they serve him very well relating both the good and bad of aspects of a time period with no internet or cell phones , but rather one with party lines , rotary dial phones and extremely gossipy neighbors . As with all time travel tales there is a price to pay for changing the time line and here as in other time altering stories the bigger the change the bigger the ripple effect . And as an unexpected bonus there is a small part where Jake Epping encounters characters from a previous King novel - really loved that part since it was from one of my all time favorite SK books ! I'll never forget when as a 6 year old in first grade the school principal interrupted the class with the news of the president getting shot - it was an event that literally stunned a nation . In the years since there have been many 'what if' stories of the president not getting assassinated , but I'd have to say this one is much more than that and the best of the genre . Mark me down as a very satisfied constant reader !

I am a longtime King fan, but I do feel that his more recent books have been uneven and I haven't loved all of them. This book seems like a return to form.  As always, King provides great character development and excellent descriptive prose that makes me feel like I am back in the last 50's right along with the protaganist (even though I wasn't alive then!).  Full disclosure, I am only about halfway through the book, as I purchased it on CD to help get me through the long drives over the holidays, but I have been so into it that I have been listening to it even during a 5 minute drive.  So far, this book seems like King's more character/story driven books (like The Stand, The Shining) rather than the more supernaturally driven books (Pet Semetary, It), but that may change towards the end (as a lot of his books seem too). Either way, I am enjoying the ride.

I'm not a Stephen King fan but I do like good science fiction and this is good.  Because of being a King book it is dark and not prone to the "happily ever after" of other books.  I found the book hard to put down even in the darker parts.  As for the history I found it very interesting, but this isn't a history book in the true sense.  It is a study of the characters and the times.  It spends most of the book giving you the feel of living in the late 50's and early 60's.  It provides very little information on the assasination or what the world would be like if Kennedy weren't assasinated.  The book is a novel.  The one thing I feared and most mentioned among my friends when I told them about reading it was that it might get really creepy, it was Stephen King after all.  The book did not and stayed true to itself as much as a time travel book can.

This is a great read, read it in four days. The story line, characters are very real, once started, had trouble putting it down. I have just one suggestion, if you have other things that need being done, don't start reading this book! Everything thing else will be put on hold.

I just finished reading this book and, simply put, I love it!  I am a fan of Stephen King although some of his past books have been difficult to read.  Not this one!  I was hooked from the very beginning.  I have always been fascinated with the events that evolved around Kennedy's assasination.  Mr. King took this event and pushed it one step further with his "time travel" ideas.  It was so easy to "live along" with Jake/George during his travels.  I highly recommend this book!  Well worth the money!

This book brings together some of my favorite obsessions: historical 'what if' explorations, time travel, JFK's presidency and assassination, and action thrillers.  It was a blast of a read, and reminded me that SK at his best is really unbeatable for an enjoyable read.

What an engrossing story! How does Mr. King do it? I believe he has a mind bubble in his own head whereby he can visit other Stephen Kings in alternate realities and  bounce ideas off of them(himself). There is no other explanation for his unending wellspring of spinal column charging stories. I can truly say that as a lifelong comic book fan and fan of such things as the Twilight Zone, this has become one of my favorite tomes of all time. Not embellishing. I couldn't stop reading it and finished very quickly. Then I was angry that I finished! I wanted to find a doorway and reset so that I could read it again without knowing what would happen! Also, I found myself falling in love with Sadie just like Jake did. I don't think that has ever happened before. Thanks Mr. King for a wonderful story that will live in my memory for a long time!

Like some of my fellow reviewers here, I have been reading Stephen King's novels, short stories and novellas for the past 30 years. He is my favorite author and he is, in many ways, the voice of his generation. 11/22/63 is definitely the best novel since at least Bag of Bones, and maybe even since The Dead Zone. How many of us long to change the past, to right past wrongs and avert past tragedies? This book is about that longing and ultimately also about living with the consequences of the events of the past. The plot is top notch, like the best of Stephen King's novels, and the book is populated with believable and well balanced characters. I tore through the whole book in a few days and really loved it. I highly recommend the book for King's fans and also those unfamiliar with his work since the book stands brilliantly on its own.

This is a mind-blowing read in terms of the possibilities raised and the repercussions presented when dealing with time travel. A compelling story told only as Stephen King could tell it, with a little bit of mystery mixed with romance, adventure and the occasional chill. The story is compelling and the book is a page turner. I couldn't help but think as I read this that King doesn't even begin to scratch the surface of all of the implications of the butterfly effect and what would happen if one went back in time and interacted with even just one person. King seems to opt for the easy, predictable ending; I must say I half expected something a bit more twisted. Instead, his ending borders on the sweet and poignant, contributing to an overall feel good and more than satisfactory reading experience.

I preordered this book the moment I became aware of it.  The date, 11/22/1963, was a life changing day for many members of Stephen King's and my generation.  It was the day that the world changed, where assassination was not a word you read in history books but a current event.  The idea of what would have happened had JFK lived is a fascinating one.  This book protrays the late 50's and early 60's as I remember them and it is a nice trip back to a time when the world felt like a safer place.  If we had the power to go back and change the past, would we and should we?  What would the consequences of altering history be?  These are the concepts King explores in this novel.  As a Stephen King fan, I would have made the journey in any case, but I found the ride truly a thrill.

As long as this book is, and as indulgent a writer as King has always been, I have to say this is one of my favorite books I've read by him.  The concept is intriguing enough, but it is the characters that really make it great.  Jake/George's falling in love with Sadie and all the consequences that follow are what kept me reading.  I personally enjoyed the minutiae of George's observations of Oswald's comings and goings.  I also think the portrayal of Oswald is very true to what is known about him.  But it was George coming to terms with what he had to do to stop Oswald and how it affected his relationship with Sadie that drove the story.  A really compelling, engrossing read that kept me interested for over eight hundred pages!

Hand's down one of the best books I have ever read.  I had read some Stephen King many years ago (Christine, Pet Semetery, Thinner) and while those were all good books, I never fully embraced his genre or niche.  So, being a little skeptical of Stephen King, but an avid reader of history, I picked this up and couldn't set it down until I was done and was sad it was over.  Although it is based on a watershed historical event, one does not need to be into the historical genre to appreciate this book.  I could visualize the characters and their environment every step of the way through the story telling and character development.  I could drone on and on about this book... but won't.  Just do yourself a favor and read it!

To be fair, if you read the negative reviews of this book (the one stars), they are pretty much dead on.  There are 300 pages in the middle of this book that couldve been condensed quite a bit. I think you can say that about many of King's books.  I read the first 300 pages in a day, dragged a little on the next 300, and couldnt wait to read the last 200.  It had just enough of that other-worldly scenario, alternate universe timeline sci fi stuff, mixed in with actual events from real history.  Some people may not have liked the ending but I thought it was great.  Again, Ive read lots of Kings books and I definitely enjoyed this one.  Just remember, I warned you about the middle of the book.

11/22/63 is not only Stephen King's best novel in years, it's one of his best novels. The genre is time travel and it's informed by Jack Finney's (The Body Snatchers) Time and Again (highly recommended also), as well as Back to the Future--but familiar ideas are always transformed by King to transcend their original source. Although at 849 pages, the novel could've been edited for pace a little, you spend time in a world you regret leaving when the journey is done, and you regret leaving the characters even more. While it's difficult to review 11/22/63 without major spoilers, I can say that it's emotional and sweet; but be forewarned that King's work always has sharp teeth.
Got this book on a Thursday and finished it up by Sunday night-one of the best book's I've read this year.  First King book I've read, so can't compare it to others

When I first saw it, I thought, "Has Stephen King gotten too big to be edited?"  Maybe so, but God is in the details.  I was compelled to keep going even though about half way through, I had a lover's quarrel with Mr. King, and vowed I would never read anything he wrote again! I don't know if I was depressed by the violence, situation, or language choices.  Did people really swear that much in the 60's?  Anyway, I had to discover how this turned out, so I kept going.  Stephen and I kissed and made up by the end, and now I need to find non-horror novels he has written, because I may become addicted not only to the story but the style in which he writes.

Once again, Stephen King just amazes me with his imagination and skill. The concept of the parallel universe and going back in time has of course been addressed by authors in the past (notably Time and Again, which King references in his notes).  However, the idea of changing history by going back in time has never been applied to such a pivotal event as the assassination of JFK.  This story is told so deftly and the subplots that are interwoven with the main story line are just as intriguing.  It all builds to a crescendo, and what made it SO much fun to read is that I really couldn't guess the outcome!  Fantastic read! Don't miss it!

This book is amazing!!!  I was captivated from the minute I started reading.  I read it the first time about 6 months ago, putting the huge book on a pillow in my lap and finishing the entire 845 pages in one week.  Recently I got a Kindle.  I bought the book for my Kindle and now I'm reading it again by holding it in one hand!  I am seeing new details I missed the first time and enjoying it even more the second time around.  This book is vintage Stephen King, the master of suspense, characterization, and imagination!  The creativity that comes from that man's mind is scary!  If you like Stephen King, you must read this one!

And Stephen King is a masterful story teller who seems to find joy in spinning a great yarn.  I'm not even done with this book but felt compelled to review it cause I'm lovin' this book.  Mr. King has such a comfortable, folksy style - it's as if his writing were effortless and he just wants to tell you a story.  For some reason, the writing feels personal - as if it's just for me.  When he used a convenient coincidence in the book and said these things happen in real life but no writer would dare use them, it felt like a private little joke.  I usually whip through a book - this one I'm pacing myself, I want it to last.

This was a HUGE disappointment.  If you are into long pointless love stories than you will like this book.  At first, I loved this book, but after the main character meets his "love interest" the book just went downhill.  Not even the ending made up for this books content.

I've been a long-time fan of King's work. My favorite book of all time had been The Stand. It's now been replaced (although I still adore The Stand) by this book. I did not want it to end, and my heart ached when it did.  If you're like me, and you've read King's works, you'll notice the references to older novels. I'm clear on fantasy vs. reality, but it almost felt like I knew Jake Epping and felt his joy as well as his pain--a testament to Mr. King's writing. 11-22-63 will stay with you long after you've put it down, and you'll remember every nuance, every pleasure, every pain for a long time to come.

My expectations were really high when I started this book.  This book not only met my expectations but surpassed them.  This time period (the 60's) has always been fascinating to me.  The politics, Vietnam, the assassinations and the music has always been interesting to me.  I love reading stories both fiction and non-fiction about this era.  Stephen King's book is one of the best I have read about the  1960's.  To be honest, this book is really one of the best I have ever read.  I felt like I was there.  I know that sounds corny but it really is true.  This book is spectacular.  It is a must-read.

Absolutely loved this book!! I was engrossed from the beginning. Most people don't realize that he's more that just a horror writer, his character development and narrative are so good.  Not since The Stand has he held my attention this way. Glad to see he ended this book well.  His last opus was Under the Dome, and while I liked the premise and the book, it seemed like King had no idea how to end it.  As a matter of fact I still don't get that ending.  Regardless this was was great from beginning to end!!  Also buy this on the Kindle - King was made for the Kindle due to the length of his books.

I really hate scary books and movies. I was very intrigued to hear the premise of this book and it sounded like something I'd enjoy. The book was FANTASTIC. Stephen King is an amazing writer (old news, of course) but the research and detail put into 11/22/63 is mind-blowing. The characters and the story were fascinating. I would pick up the book, start reading, and 3 hours would go by in what seemed like minutes. Just amazing. I will probably read it again in the future, and I just found out that it will be turned into a 9-hour mini-series on Hulu that JJ Abrams will be directing. I CAN'T WAIT.

Early in his writing career, Stephen King was one of my favorite authors. But as time went on, his novels became weaker and weaker. What happened to the author of 'The Shining', 'The Stand', 'The Bachmann Books'? Well I guess he just came back. I think that this book will be considered Stephen King's masterpiece. I am not sure if those who do not remember the assassination of Kennedy will ever realize how truly traumatic this was. Even the protagonist of the novel is born too late to realize it. But he learns. The hard way. I read this entire novel in two days and loved every minute of it.

A few months ago, I heard about this book. Realizing its' length convinced me to purchase a Kindle. I downloaded the book the day it was released.  In only 4 days, I had completed an amazing adventure.  As a longtime King fan, I thought "The Stand" was his masterpiece. Now, I'm not so sure.  Few books have made me as emotional as I became reading this book.  The ending is pure magic. With tears in my eyes, I realized the perfect story of Jake and Sadie was at an end. Only one problem for me now...finding a new book to read after this great story!!! Nothing will measure up!!

This is my first Stephen King book, and I can't put it down, yet I don't want to finish it.  I'm a baby boomer, and the setting brings back so many wonderful memories of drive-in movies, soda fountains, and unlocked doors.  I remember exactly where I was the day President Kennedy was shot -I was in my last period in Mr. Shippey's biology class.  We were let out of school immediately, and my family was glued to our tv set the entire weekend.  I love the rich details of this novel and the development of the characters.  Kudos, Mr. King.  I will check out more of your books!

I started reading Steven King when his first novel came out and loved it. Then I read a bunch after that. In the past 15 years I have not really read anything by him. I had forgotten what an incredible novelist he is. He can take the unbelievable and make it believable. I read this book in a long weekend. However, I can not get it out of my mind. I wish I still had more to read. I think I will pick up some other Steven Kings books, that previously i had not read because I thought they were too much like science fiction. He takes science fiction and makes it seem real.

I am a constant reader. I love just about everything Stephen King does. I could not get into the Dark Tower series but have read just about everything else. This novel was a nice change of pace for the author but had some classic Stephen King elements as well. A man is shown a time portal in a diner. This portal leads to the same day in 1958. The owner of the diner convinces him to go back, wait 5 years and stop the Kennedy asassination. The book was well reasearched, the concept was not new but well played out. I liked the ending. Can't wait for the next book.

This is in a class with his best novels (which were the early ones in my opinion.) It's suspenseful, but without the usual horror in his stories. His treatment of time travel has a unique slant, but is internally consistent and isn't too gimmicky. King's stories always start out well, though occasionally fizzle out (most notably It.) This one keeps up the pace and I particularly liked the way he ended it. One of his best endings. He even throws in a nod to It, when his main character encounters some of the kids from It. Overall, excellent.

Having read every one of King's books, I feel like a pseudo expert on his efforts. I loved this book from page one and it got better as it neared the final pages[900+]. For the first time ever I wanted to go to the last pages to see how it ended before I finished it. Maybe Stephen is mellowing in his old age but this effort was by far his best. He is known for his out of this world stories with horror being the key ingredient. This story had substance, great story line, you name it. It was hard to put down. Congrats on a great effort.

I always love Steven King's writing, and I was not disappointed in this book.  It is a very large book, and I'll admit there were a few (very few) places where maybe I would have preferred a little less information.  However, with that being said, he did an amazing job creating characters (George and Sadie).  Long after I finished the book, their presence lingered in my mind. I love when a character becomes so real and fully dimensional that there's a sense of loss when I'm done with the book. I would definitely recommend the read.

I'll admit this right off... I love Stephen King. Always have, always will, everything he has ever written is over the top outrageously good.  11/22/63 is a bit of a departure for him, one that I'm so glad he took; I go willingly anywhere he wants to take me. I have no problem hiding under the covers shaking with fear, or wandering from the past to the present, listening to his music and facing my fears. You're always in good hands and his books are always an adventure into the mind of a literary genius. Rage on Stephen.

I've recommended it to everyone and bought it for 2 other people.  I chose it as a selection for my book club and they all loved it.  I felt like I was actually in those historical times and places and could watch events unfold up close.  What a way to look at the ramifications of "what if" and to see into the mind and personal life of one of our country's most infamous villains.  When I finished the book I had to remind myself that it was mostly fiction.  (And I loved how he handled the ending!)

I read roughly 1 book a week and it has been a very long time since I puchased one I couldn't put down.  This is the first and only Stephen King book I have ever read and it was definately a page turner.  After only two days I finished it and was surprised at how fun it was to read.  I have to say I am a sap and the story line between Jake and Sadie was the biggest reason I kept pushing forward, but you should definately buy this book.  Most readers will not be disappointed.

I had trouble getting into this book in the first 150 pages. I kept putting it down, not sure if I wanted to finish. But once I got to about page 200 I couldn't put the book down. So much to think about and so many great characters. I have always loved Stephen King's books, and while this is a departure from the horror genre, it's well-written and has left me thinking about the characters and the repercussions of changing the past long after I finished the last page.

I love time travel novels, but this one is a page-turner for sure! At a friend's request, Jake goes back to 1958 to be around to save JFK in 1963. Along the way, he saves others, falls in loves, gets beat up and talks with some famous people. I loved it because every time I guessed how it would end, the plot suddenly turns in a different direction. My only regret is that I bought the hardcover - get the Kindle version to save you from carrying around this heavy book!

Haven't read a Stephen King novel since college over 25 years ago! Picked this book up in the bookstore, read the jacket and it sounded good. Good, huh, this book was great!! Love, love, loved this book from cover to cover. If you have the idea that all Stephen King novels are horror/scary, you will be pleasantly surprised when you pick up this book. This is history meets time travel meets romance. Definitely a book to keep on my shelf and read again!

I've never read a Stephen King novel before, but I started this on Friday and finished it on Monday. I was completely absorbed. It's the work of a man who knows how to write. I wondered how he'd end it, since it's pretty complex. In the hands of a less-experienced writer, it could have fallen apart, but it didn't at all. A brilliant, compelling yarn - one I can't get put of my head. It's been ages since I felt this connected to a novel. Bravo, King!

A "constant reader" since I was 13 , this is easily one of his best works . I have not been drawn into a story or characters like this in a very long time . As many reviews suggest , its all about character and while the story itself is not eye popping , the cast itself gives the novel a life of its own . Very well paced , but not overly exciting . Great scenery and perspective for a time travel tome . A MUST READ EVEN FOR NON KING FANS .

I read a lot ... but not Stephen King ... most of his stuff is not the kind of stuff that appeals to my reading pleasure.  But when I read about this book it intrigued me enough to pre-buy it to be downloaded to my Kindle.  And I was not sorry.  It was a great read and quite nostalgic for me since I grew up in the 50's and 60's.  Brought back a lot of memories ... both good and sad.  I have recommended this book to all my reader friends.

I'm not generally a reader of science fiction or horror but when this book made it to the top slot on the New York Times bestseller fiction list, I figured I'd give it s shot. Our library had it on 7 day loan. Could I read this monster (849 pages) in that time frame? Indeed I did ... because the tale was captivating engrossing. King weaves a hundred tales into this book and manages to tie up all the loose ends. In fact, a number of times the twists really made me smile at his uncanny ability. Coming from a non-fiction reader, I can say the book is well worth the read.

It has been a long time since I sat up all night to read a book. It took me two sittings. The second was 24 hours long. This book just restored my love of Stephen King's writing. It never really disappeared but this book was just amazingly engrossing. I do think part of my immersion in the story was having the JFK assassination being my first memories. I would recommend it to anyone though.

Here's a new book by the King of Horror.  11/22/63.  I don't read novels or stories by Stephen King.  I know. I know.  I'm an adult, but I still have bad dreams.  I say it's because I am incredibly creative and have a vivid imagination--I have to blame it on something.  Don't judge this book by it's author; it's not what you think when you hear "Stephen King."  Read this book!

This book was phenomenal!  It kept me on the edge of my seat for the entire long haul (849 pages), not knowing where the story might end-up.  You become attached to all the main characters and really care about them.  Notwithstanding the length of the book, King does not get bogged down in a lot of extraneous and unnecessary detail.  You will love it!

Could hardly put it down.  A worm hole and time travel were not what I expected & usually don't care for Stephen King, but this novel was great!  I can't imagine the research and time he put in figuring out all the angles and repercussions of Jake's interference with history.  I learned a lot about the events leading up to this historical event if it was all true according to his research.  I would recommend it to history buffs!

It's been years since I read a Steven King novel, and I read this one only because of the raves of my youngest offspring, who was born eight years after the shocking assassination of 11/22/63. Although that era is history to her, to me it is like yesterday. Not only is the concept of time travel interesting to me, for it to be served up ala King made 11/2/63 a must-read. I finished this book minutes ago, and it did not disappoint. Once again I not only fell in love once with King's inimitable style and sense of story but was impressed by the maturation of his writing; I've been a King reader since the beginning. I had fallen out of the habit of reading fiction since I began writing a memoir around the turn of the century and penning another book since that time. Born in 1942, 11/22/63 was a stepping back in time for me, as my memoirs would be for Mr. King. I recommend this part-time for anyone who lived through the 50s and 60s and anyone who is interested in going back to visit that era, only with feet planted firmly in their world of today.

11-22-63 brought back hundreds, maybe thousands, of my own memories of being raised in Dallas and in Texas in the early 60s. I love time travel novels, and this one is now in my Top 3: Time and Again, Time Traveler's Wife, and now 11-22-63. Each had a great story at its heart, each was a love story with a fabulous romance, and in each case, a reluctant hero thrust into the role of a super hero by the fact that he knows what will happen next. Such great stories, and of these, 11-22-63 is The Best. It is an addictive page turner. Five stars!

Today is a fitting day for me to be leaving this review, being the 50th anniversary of the death of JFK. Stephen King novels are not usually my jam, but this book was recommended by so many people that I knew from various age groups and tastes, all with the same glowing praise. They were all completely right. I blew off plans, twice, because I had to keep reading. I haven't been this taken with a book in years. It sucks you in completely and I know it's just a matter of time before I reread it again.

I have been a devoted Stephen King fan ever since 'Carrie' and have read all his books, novellas and short stories.  11/22/63 resonated with me on many levels.  I was 22 when JFK was assassinated and I will never forget that awful time.  This book brought all of those events into a mesmerizing story that I could not put down. I personally think there is no other writer out there with Mr. King's ability to frame a story with his incredible use of language. I laughed and I cried reading this book and felt like I was back in 1963 again. I strongly recommend this book for those who lived through those times and especially for those for whom it is only history.
I have always enjoyed Stephen Kings way of looking at things.  A very good read. Thoroughly enjoyed the story. Read it.
Riveting.  Completely riveting from start to finish.  Even if you are not a King fan, this is a must read.
I could not put this down.  I'm afraid I was a lousy parent that week.  Best on kindle so you can't peek so easily at the ending.
I  usually don't care for Stephen King but this book is an exception. Fascinating from a historical perspective as well as a great personal story.
Loved the concept, the refresher history lesson and the story behind things! The grass is always greener, but is it?

The best story I ever read by King, no exaggeration.  I literally did not want it to end.  Time travel stories are tricky, but he does so well with this by not attempting to explain overly much about exactly how it happened or why

I have read many time travel stories (even writing my own since 1999). This one is gripping, not so much for the actual idea behind the main plot, but for all of the little details that pull you in and take you along for the ride. Sex, violence, humor, love, intrigue -- this book is full of the stuff of life, including food, music and dancing. Some things are timeless and universal. This story illustrates that exceptionally well. Life is worth living.
This book is amazing.  I really was so sad when i realized Jack and Sadie were not to be.  The whole adverture was so real when I would get lost in the pages.
Could not put this down.  Love a lot, not al of King's work.  This, is one of the best.  I even read it while I was drying my hair, that's how page turning I found it to be.

Clearly Stephen King has devised some form of visual hypnosis with the pattern of his words to induce a reader to ignore their spouse, their children, their job, and their sleep patterns just to find out what happens next. I have blazed through this book in the last few days and am left with a pretty cool feeling of exhilaration and wonder like I'm stepping off of an unexpectedly extended roller coaster ride. This was a thrilling read and I highly recommend it!

This was the first book I bought on my Kindle and I certainly wasn't disappointed. I loved absolutely everything about this novel: the plot, the pace and the characters. I have read a number of King books previously and the reason I keep coming back for more is that I think he is unparalleled when it comes to creating and sustaining memorable characters and places. The biggest compliment I can pay this novel is that I couldn't wait to get to the end of the book but simultaneously I dreaded reaching the conclusion as it would mean the end of my time in the world of the story.  As a testament to King's storytelling skills he succeeded in making me feel nostalgic for a time and place that I have never inhabited. One criticism I would have of other King novels is that I am rarely satisfied with the endings, however, I think this one is perfect. Prior to 11.22.63 my favorite book by King was 'The Stand' but this one has definitely replaced it at the top of the list.

This was very different from your standard King boogeyman book. There was the feeling of something hovering just out of sight that was threatening, but the story played out, beautifully, with only that feeling of threat, until it came to bear. King is still a master wordsmith, and he unravels the characters and the story masterfully. I loved this book, but there is so much I can't write into a review without spoiling it. Just understand -- there is no killer clown, no Randal Stark-- the villain is much more complex and more troubling in the end. I was enjoyed the hell out of this, in spite of it not being horror.

Thirty years ago I read everything Stephen King wrote. In the ensuing years I lost interest in his writing and stopped reading his books. I am not sure why I bought 11/22/63, but I am sure glad I did. I found the book riveting. I won't describe any of the plot as it is just too fun to experience first hand. Suffice it to say that it has my unqualified recommendation.

In my ignorance I had always assumed that all Stephen King books were horror-themed.  Horror does not float my boat so I had never read any of his books. However, I had heard he was an astonishingly talented writer.  11/22/63 showed me that in every line of every page.  It is a brilliant idea, executed impeccably by a writer who I can only assume is 'at the height of his powers' (an overused but totally appropriate phrase).  From the arresting title...to the brilliant premise... to the expertly navigated minefield of time travel writing...to the characters and their relationships it is all utterly absorbing. I defy you not to be moved by the dance scenes and a certain re-imagined newspaper headline.  At the end of my copy, the author describes how he thought about writing this book 40 years ago.  He decided against it because of the huge amount of research involved and the fact that, 9 years after JFK's assassination, it was still too raw.  I also imagined a further reason (apologies for putting words in your mouth, Mr. King!) - a massive amount of confidence (in his writing and his premise)  and a full life of relationships and world events experience have elevated this book way beyond what it might have been 40 years ago.  I was intrigued, enthralled, moved, scared, addicted, educated, and just plain old entertained.

In true Stephen King fashion this book had me hooked from the first. Ive been a King fan for years and I'm still amazed at his seemingly limitless imagination. 11/22/63 is a fascinating trip through the past and a jaunt down memory lane for those readers who grew up during this time period. I found myself longing to travel back myself to a period before computers, internet and electronic gadgetry. I did have a hard time trying NOT to read into the underlying political views that I'm not sure are just a fabrication of the story line or perhaps a bit of Kings own personal beliefs. Either way this book is a must read and one you will have a hard time putting down if you are a Stephen King fan.

"11/22/63" is probably my favorite Stephen King book ever.  As a teenager I devoured his books, even doing a final class report comparing one of his short stories against an HG Wells story.  My other favorite book of his is The Stand, which is an amazing journey through an entire universe, similar to this story.  I had not picked up any of his books in many years, but what a return.  His tone and pace of storytelling was familiar and great to revisit, and I was pulled into the world of this story quickly and had a hard time putting the book down.  It made for great reading while I was spending a lot of time on airplanes as I was transported to another place literally and figuratively.  If you enjoy a fully engaging story with intense characters, and aren't afraid of a long read, I highly recommend this book.

In the search for a good book to read, I fell prey to the marketing hype before this book was released.  The order placed on Amazon, I decided to read another Stephen King book while I was waiting for the release of "11/22/63", so I ordered "Under the Dome" as a time filler and to get me in the mood for "11/22/63".  Unfortunately, I gave up on "Under the Dome" about 1/2 way through, because it was too ugly, gruesome, depressing, and too vividly portrayed man's inhumanity to man. "11/22/63" finally arrived and sat unread on my Kindle as a result of my experience with "Under the Dome." When I finally started "11/22/63", I was carried away by it and could not put it down.  The writing was classically, beautiful Stephen King's writing, with a plot and story line that captured me and would not let go.  After more than a thousand pages, I was still not ready for it to finish. For me, this was a beautiful love story woven around time travel and vivid characters set in the late 1950's and early 1960's.  I believe that this is a book that Stephen King fans and non fans alike will relish.  After all of Stephen King's successes, he certainly doesn't need to prove that he is one of the best story tellers ever to entertain us, but he proved it again with "11/22/63'. I do hope he keeps on proving it as long as he can.

I'm a fan of King's other novels and I wasn't sure how well he would be able to pull off the alternative history genre. I was impressed that King was able to maintain his characteristic tense, fast-paced writing style even here. The final ~250 pages in particular were very "edge of your seat." I actually finished the final third of this novel in one sitting because it was so riveting. Great pacing, great historical accuracy, and a great story make this book worth 5 stars in my opinion.

After reading quite a few reviews of this book, I expected it to be a long hard read. Most people stated that they thought the mid section of the book was way to drawn out and really not necessary to the story line. From my reading experience this book was thoroughly enjoyable start to finish, and I think that all parts were relevant and went to making the story more believable.
