I'm not usually a huge fan of Stephen King but a friend suggested this book and it was really very good. Its a long book but it reads pretty fast and can keep your attention.

I just could not put this book down until I finished reading it. Anything is  possible, and with the historical research involved, this was a very enjoyable/sentimental novel.  I only wish more people were told about the find!

An epic novel that combines historical fiction with time travel!  Anyone who has interest in this time and in the assassination of JFK will love this book.  It has action, adventure, historical references, a love story, fantasy and time travel!  Add to that a moral worth considering...be careful what you wish for!  WOW!  A great testament to the value of cultural literacy!!  Well done.

Oh man! This book has heart man, it has heart! I loved it! There was one spot where it slowed down a little more than my liking, but for the tone and style of the book, it did a surprising job of pulling me through most of it. It's told in first person, which is pretty rare these days - and I thought it worked brilliantly. It has such a personal feel because the protagonist is the narrator. I bet first person is going to come back. Don't believe me? Ever heard of a novel called The Hunger Games? Yeah I thought so :) I really cared about these characters. I think King's biggest strength is writing good characters. I didn't know how he was going to end this huge story leaving me satisfied, but he did - and he did it in a way I wasn't expecting. I liked this book so much, I know it is one that will join the few books I will most certainly go back and read again someday. If you've never read King because you're not a horror fan like me - you owe it to yourself to give this one a try. I think you'll find that there's a reason Stephen is the King when it comes to speculative fiction. Also, I wasn't too sure about the narrator Craig Wasson at first, but as the story came alive through his voice it grew on me to the point where I can't imagine another voice telling this story. He has the perfect voice for the main character, and his accents were great too! I really enjoyed his read of this amazing novel.
Stephen King is absolutely the best story-teller of our generation. The best written historical fiction piece in decades. Bravo, Stephen!
The old Steven King is back.  This is the best book I've read in awhile.  I felt like I went right back in time with the main character.

I may be a bit biased at the Kennedy subject and that, along with the name of the author made me buy this book as soon as it became available.  I was plainly wrong.  This book is not about Kennedy; but my god what a plot!  I recommend it to everybody. A real page turner!

The book is really awesome. I had given up on Stephen King sometime ago, just lost interest, but this book has made me a fan again.  I am listening to the audio (three MP3 audios) so it's not a short book but boy is it good!
Just finished reading 11/22/63.  Although I usually don't read Stephen King books, I did read this one.  Could not put it down.

I love King and most of his books. This was beyond great though. What fun to speculate what you would do if you could save JFK? Its a book I can finally recommend to those who always say oh I am not into HIS books. Because this is so different. I loved going back to when you could buy a caddilac convertible for under 500bucks and a soda for five cents. What fun. I didn't love toward the end and he went back to the pretty bleak reality even though i knew he would probably go that direction somewhere in the book and seven though i knew it could be undone but otherwise, fun to get lost in the 60's and also learner a lot about the history of that time, even enjoyed the speculative conversations with Oswald etc.

I'm giving this 5 stars because I couldn't put it down! It was beautifully written, if a bit repetitive at times. I'm going to be completely honest, there were a few things that bothered me, (as already mentioned many times by other reviewers), some of the overly repeated words: Obdurate!!! Harmonizes!!! Poundcake! Broom! I was also hoping for more on the yellow, orange, black, ocher, green card man/men. However, I'm still not entirely convinced that wasn't just more ingenious writing. I'm not going to over-analyze the fanciful plot or claim that Mr. King has some political agenda. It's just a fun, absorbing, fictitious book by one of the most adept imaginative writers of our time! It was fantastic and I loved it!

I've had my ups and downs with Stephen King's books but this is definitely one I thoroughly enjoyed.  The story itself is intriguing -- it gets you thinking.  It's a well told story with well defined characters.

As always, King does it again! Great book and makes you think... What if... I love the way he always makes his stories so realistic.. His ending are as life really would work out, not always the happy ever after like a lot of books! The main charature has many conflicting emotions that us mere mortals would have! This book has every thing... Romance,murder,compation... And covers every emotion ... Great job! Great book! Highly recomended... From King I would't expect any thing less!
Like many other readers I am not a Stephen King fan, but I could not put down this book.  I finished the book a week ago and I still can't stop thinking about the book!!  This is a must read!!

This is absoulutely the best book I have ever read.  Suspense from beginning to end with a great love story thrown in.  I literally read it into the wee hours of the night until my eyeballs were burning.

I was grabbed by this book from the beginning....LOVED IT from beginning to end....great concept of time travel with a combination of history & romance....One of King's best works every in my opinion....You will not be sorry on this one....

I've been reading Stephen King since the early 80's and have read pretty much all his books and have all of the ones from the Stephen King Library.  Nobody can paint a picture of the 50's and 60's like Stephen King does with his love of the cars and music from that era.  He also shows how far we have come since then with the ignorance and prejudice of the time, although we still have a long way to go.  I was sucked in from the first few pages and enjoyed not just the idea of the time travel but what was also a true love story that I didn't know Stephen King had in him.  I won't provide anything that will be called a spoiler but will say if you enjoy the classics like The Shining, Salem's Lot, Christine, The Dead Zone, and The Stand....I put this up there with those titles.  It was probably the best money I have spent on a book in years.

In a nutshell, this story was amazing! It kept you on the edge of your seat the whole time. I don't even remember a "slow" part in the book. I couldn't, nor did I want to put it down. I will say that just from reading the "details" about what the book is about.....that's not what it's really about. It's not that cut and dry at least. I'll just say this....it's not what you think....it's better.

king engages you from the very first page. i think i read the entire book with my eyes wide open. i love the paradoxical possibilities and alternate realities time travel creates. this book did not disappoint. probably one of the most satisfying endings despite leaving me longing for more for jake.

I was excited to read this book because of the thought of exploring an alternate history.  While that exploration is not very long, I was surprised to find that I was more compelled by the love story that takes place through most of the book.  Also, the thriller-esque portrayal of trying to change the past is gripping.

First time experience with this medium (MP3 Audio CD).  Discovered that my home CD player could not play this.  However, my automobile CD player did play it.  Also played very well on computer (Windows Media Player) where I could easily access stopping/starting locations.  However, in vehicle, much more difficult as the "skip" function recognized only the 4 main divisions of the CD.  One would have to manually "fast forward" through hours of real time data to find stopping/starting location.  I routinely do most of my listening in car on commute to and from work, however, I ended up listening to this primarily via computer.  Nice to have only one disc.  Great book!

11-22-63 By Stephan King A delightful book with a strong main character that Mr. King is known to write. There is a spot in an old dinner in Lisbon, Main - Al's Dinner, that when you go through it, it takes you back to September 9, 1958 at 11:58a. Same time, same place each time you entered it. No matter how long you were gone, you were only gone two minutes in 2011. Al Templeton showed it to Jack Epping, English teach at the local high school and a valued customer. Al was dying of lung cancer and couldn't finish the task he had set himself. After years of using the portal to buy low cost meat for his dinner, and taking vacations - because he was only gone two minutes in Lisbon of now, he would take two weeks or a month's worth of time off in 1958 - he got the idea of changing history, now he wanted Jack to complete the task for him. Live in the past, from September 9 th , 1958 to November 22 nd , 1963 and stop Lee Harvey Oswald from killing President John Fitzgerald Kennedy. Jack went back for a little over a month to do his own experiment, stopping a man in Derry, Main from killing his wife, two of his sons, his daughter and injuring his youngest son with permanent brain damage and a limp. Being the fall after the deaths caused by Pennywise the Clown, there was still an air of mistrust and evil around the town, and the evil was centered at the Kitchener Ironworks, which he was sent to inspect as part of his cover of a real estate broker. He knew of this homicide because one of his adult education students was the surviving son, his essay of The Day that Changed My Life had made Jack cry as he read of the horror of that Halloween Night as Frank Dunning took drunken revenge on the wife that had kicked him out of her house for beating her and the children. He was a little late, and Frank killed his wife Doris and injured his oldest son. When he got back to 2011, he took Al home and when back to his house and slept 14 hours. When he got up he researched the son he had saved, he found that he had died in Vietnam because he had a guardian angel and took more chances that he would have without seeing Jack there that night and having him say to him "I am your angel, I won't let any harm come to you." Jack went to tell Al that the experiment was a failure, to find that Al had died in the night, leaving him a note that he had to finish the task. So, Jack went back, and killed Frank Dunning two weeks before that fateful night and then went on to save a young girl from getting shot and paralyzed (Al big experimental task) and then went on to find a time to kill Lee Harvey Oswald and find the proof needed that he was the only one in on the conspiracy. This book as we moved into Lee Harvey Oswald life was so full of various historical facts about all the players of that fateful day in American history, that I was sent looking up players and facts to make sure they had really accrued and to find out more about them. Mr. King followed Mr. Oswald's life pretty accurately from the time he got to Dallas. The delight to this reviewer in this creation of Mr. King's was the fact that the history was so vividly written, and the facts woven into a story so gripping that you couldn't put it down until your eyes refused to stay open and see the page any longer. A world of shifting time lines, fact and fictional characters woven into a beautiful piece of work that you want to enjoy more than once. Mr. King wove through this story a beautiful romance that broke your heart, not once, but twice as the lines shifted and moved again. This story is a definite read for anyone who loves Mr. King's works, not horror, but delightful story with mystical paranormal elements that will keep you guessing to its outcome. A compelling read for anyone that loves history, and is interested in the players surrounding the JFK assassination. I give this book a five star rating for the thoughts and reasoning behind one man's task at saving the world. As Mr. King put in his explanation, this is one possible outcome and theory or what might have happened that day, and if that day had never happened.

But still awesome!!! I'm a lifelong fan of Stephen King. I love his horror novels, but when I saw this one I was reluctant to read it. My mother bought it for me as a present as she was reading it and loved it. Once I started to read I couldn't put it down. Even though it's not usual Stephen King, I think it's one of his best. I couldn't believe how well-researched it was and the story is amazing. I found the political history as interesting as the story about Jake Epping, the main character. Highly recommended!

I read this book faster than I have read a book in a long time. It was a very exciting story with a great homage to the past and time travel. The story was a series of events that made it east to read and in a good way left me looking for more just like this one. Great job Mr. King.

I thought 11/22/63 was an awesome book, I couldn't put it down, I would easily give this book between 4 1/2 - 5 stars,  I've been reading Stephen King's books for about the past 20 years, and I have to admit he would be by far, the greatest horror writer alive, he constantly keeps the audience on the edge of their seats, and that's the main reason I love reading his books, I would be surprised if he ever wrote non-fiction, but I would still read it, If you're a King reader I would STRONGLY suggest you buy 11/22/63, you will not be disappointed.

Thus has to be one of the "best" books I have read in years!  I was 9 years old when JFK was killed and I can still tell you where I was and what I was doing when I heard and saw the news flash!!  It has had a life long impact on me!  This book took me back to those days.  As a kid I played like the kids on the streets named in SK best book ever!  It took me back to the sites and sounds of my youth.  I have read almost everything on JFK since I became old enough to understand the impact his lfe and death had on me and our.country!  SK melds fact and fiction into the most compelling story I've ever read. Well Done Mr. King!!

There are plenty of reviews that give a good synopsis of this book, so I won't give another. I will say that I thought this was a fantastic book. I have not read many S.K. books but the plot of this one intreagued me. I would recommend this book to anyone.
A great book right from the beginning.  A book about JFK and portals as only Stephen King could write it.  Love, love, loved it.  Highly recommend this book.  It is a must read.

I will have to admit (although people will probably think that I'm crazy), but this was the first ever SK book I have ever read. I, for one, am not a big book reader to say the least. Usually when I start to read a book, I lose interest. That, however, was not the case with this book. I was truly captivated throughout the magnificent journey that is this book. It took me about four weeks to read it, as I have a very busy schedule with not a lot of downtime. I must say that my next Kindle purchase will probably be a King book. His character building is phenomenal. I do not know how this particular book stacks up against his other works, but I cannot emphasize enough how much I truly enjoyed this book. I will say that I made time to read the last 100 pages in one night. I just couldn't put it down. I am pretty sure that this would be a box office smash if it were ever made into a movie. Of course, a lot would rely on the cast of characters and director.

I'm a fan.  I'm also not easily impressed.  I read to much to be that.  But, I have to say that this one is King's obstinate refusal.  To what I don't know.  I don't care.  The characters are people I want to meet.  Not that I'd always be nice or anything.  The songs are songs that I wanna listen to again.  Derry is still a place with clowns and I'm betting King has two left feet.  But this novel makes you want to laugh, cry, dance, have some poundcake and finally OBDERATE.  "And if he doesn't regret it and remains obdurate, we shall just have to kill him."

Highly recommended.  When I finished it, I thought... 'ok, now I know how it really happened'.  Then realized no, it was a fictional story.  But it made me really think about it.  I always wondered about time travel and the repercussions that can occur.  Stephen King, of course, is an awesome writer.  He gave a story that most people, no matter their reading preferences, would enjoy.  I know I'll read it again.  It was that good.

Until this book I hadn't finished a Stephen King book in years ... I loved his early books, grew away from them as I got older, and the last time I tried to return to them I didn't enjoy the books.  I just couldn't get into them.  When I saw the positive reviews for this book I figured I'd give King another try, and I'm glad I did.  This was an excellent, well-written story.  I enjoyed it completely.

Although my Stephen King days are in the past ( having given up horror and science fiction novels) I was enticed to listen to this on audio because of my undying interest in the Kennedy assassination.  True to the publisher's notes, this has very little to do with science fiction and everything to do with history and its impact. It is highly readable, very modern, with a story line that has something for everyone.  I think the novel is especially relevant for those who were alive and cognizant during the fifties and sixties.  I also believe that King has concluded in a way that is natural and necessary, not particularly how we might wish, but how it had to be.  I just could not put it down. I wanted to dole it out in small doses, but I was too greedy for the next chapter.

There is only one time travel story - the protagonist travels forward/backward in time and ends up affecting his own real time - sometimes intentionally but more often as an unintended consequence.  What a delicious twist Stephen King has given us on this theme!  Those of us who lived through it recall those glamorous days of the Kennedy Administration as Camelot, a time of wholeness, happiness and innocence.  King takes us back to those glory days, but exposes the hidden underbelly of political division, sexual hypocrisy, racism and paranoia that permeated Camelot as a result of rigid ideologies, evolving male/female roles, Jim Crow laws and the creeping Cold War.  America's dreams were dashed on 11/22/63 by a grandiose pipsqueak named Lee Harvey Oswald, who in all probability was the lone gunman who assassinated JFK. Our protagonist Jake Epping/George Amberson seeks to prevent that tragedy and change the course of history in order to save young soldiers who would certainly be "invited to put on uniforms, fly to the other side of the world, spread their nether cheeks, and sit down on the big green dildo that was Vietnam." In the course of his journey to Dallas for that fateful date, our paladin finds other wrongs along the way that need to be righted. . .only to find that "the past is obdurate; it doesn't want to change."  And what he is able to affect against the intractability of history, creates all manner of unintended consequences.  Jake's journey through the time travel wormhole is a nostalgia trip with a bracing dose of stark realism, a thrilling journey, a touching love story, and a rueful acknowledgement that the past is obdurate.  It doesn't want to change-- and there may well be good cosmic reasons for that.  The book is unputdownable.

Stephen King at his best!  I've read nearly everything he's written and for those who may shy away thinking King is only a "horror" novel writer, you don't know what you're missing.  Many of his novels, including this one, are not horror but truly a psychological journey into a world he has created with the imagination of a genius.  I will read this one again and again.

In my humble opinion, this is one of King's best novels in years.  I was worried at the length of the book, thinking the story might get bogged down in places.  I was pleasantly surprised that it kept me fully engrossed throughout.  In fact, the last half of the book which focuses on the Kennedy/Oswald storyline was a page-turner for me.  I finished the last 400 pages in a day.  The characters are well developed.  The time travel aspect (always a fun topic for me) was well presented.  Although there is some violence throughout, it is fairly tame in that regard when compared to some of King's other more "horrific" works.  In other words, don't avoid this because you don't like the horror genre.  This one is different and offers something for almost everyone.

I just finished this book (not on my Kindle, there are just some books you have to hold in your hands and smell the ink) and I loved it! It makes you want to live in that era (if you didn't to begin with) but in the next chapter you are glad that you were born later. It gets you involved with the characters so much that you can feel their happiness and their pain. A great read!

This was right up my alley. I'm just going to assume it was written for me. King made the character my age, there are two characters with the names of my children, and I'm a big Jack Finney fan. I really felt the spirit of Finney in this, and little did I know that King was thinking the same thing and came close to dedicating this to him, opting to honor his granddaughter instead. I'll just chalk all these coincidences up to the harmonics of too many strings.

I read this book over my Thanksgiving break, to the chagrine of my semi-neglected family. Other reviewers have gone into a lot of depth about the plot and ideas presented in this book, so I won't waste your time here recounting the subtle nuances of King's alternate history ideas. I literally could not put this book down. Some of the passages are the sweetest, most tenderly written desciptions of love and attraction available anywhere; and some of the passages bring the reader to near tears for the physical and mental suffering these characters endure. It is a great escape and a wonderful literary voyage. Congrats, Mr. King, I can't wait for the movie!

Just finished it and love it.  I haven't read much King (horror is not my favorite genre) and some popular authors are surprisingly bad writers.  Fortunately, King is not one of these and indeed writes very well.  I was impressed that he could make me feel tenderness, hope, dread, nostalgia, and weave in the many details where the past itself provides the main conflict of the story.  This is the best popular novel I have read in several years.  Very well done.

Stephen King has a way of walking me along side his characters. His words know exactly how create the perfect movie in my mind. With this book his dynamic writing has you not only seeing the story but smelling era and feeling the pain. Kings works are by far one of the most anticipated works on my reading list!

This will be a short review.  11/22/63 is a story of love, history, and the enormity of every step one takes. This is not a horror as most of King's books are. It is a look into the past, and the moments that led up to Kennedy's death. It is a glimpse at how different the world could be if the JFK assassination was prevented. King did an incredible job as always. I was drawn into the story and had a hard time putting this book down. I finished this book far faster than any other 800+ page book I've ever read. King has a way of describing the past that puts you right there with him. As a child of the 80's, going back to the 50's was an exciting adventure. I could almost taste the root beer at 'The Fruit'. Bravo, Stephen King.  - One of your biggest fans, Melissa from Houston, Texas

Interesting idea for a novel.  King applies his usual readable style.  The story is complex but never confusing.  A different take on familiar time travel themes and it works very well.  Doesn't quite pack the punch of earlier epics like "The Stand" but still effective novel with a wide scope.  A few *deep* ideas mixed in with what is really pop entertainment.  Worth a read for King fans and non-fans alike.

I was completely surprised by how beautiful and how moving this book is. I rushed through it, turned around, and started it again. What a tremendous book. Much more like Time Traveller's Wife in terms of beautiful writing than most of Stephen King's books. Well worth the length of the book.

GREAT read... So much better than The Dome which left reader ready to throw the book!  I am an avid King lover and found this to be one of his best.  This book actually had a logical ending that left reader content unlike his last few novels.  If you new to King... give this one a try...

This book grabs your attention from the beginning and doesn't let it go.  I read it in two days and couldn't put it down.  I have liked some of King's work in the past and this one ranks with "The Stand" as some of his best work.  Even if you don't like Kings work , you will like this.

I've read Stephen King since I was a kid.  I've seen him go from tales of psychic phenomenon to horror and now to modern day revisions of history.  There is nothing this guy can't write about and the plot development along with character development are nothing short of incredible.

This has been said many times; "Stephen King has done it again." However, I think this truly is his crowning achievement. He took one of the most darkest events in the history of America and turned it into an epic journey combining actual events and people along with fictional events and characters. The story beings with the main character, Jake Epping (I love how the last name describes him. Epping meaning he goes on an Epic journey), a high school/GED teacher who's friend, Al Templeton owns a diner that has a time portal in it's pantry. The time portal transfers anyone who walks in there to September 9th, 1958. Al who is now sick and dying of lung cancer asks Jake to go back in time to prevent the Kennedy Assassination. After Al briefs him on how the time portal works and how to be careful in the past, Jake agrees to carry on the mission not only for his dying friend but for America itself. Not only does Jake, who now goes by the name George Amberson in the past try to prevent JFK's death, he also prevents other past dangers from happening while also making a new life for himself. On the book jacket of this book, it tells us that the story portrays time travel as more realistic. This book surely does. I won't go into detail on how because those who haven't read it yet need to read it for themselves. The things that I really like about this book is how King has actual people interact with fictional characters. I also like how detailed the book is. In other words; there's an explanation for everything. Probably my most favorite part of the book is the price. The price for saving a person's life. I won't give any spoilers away but I will say this; saving John F. Kennedy's life. Those who were living in 1963 remember how sad and unsafe they felt but, what would have happened to the country had he lived? I know that most people like to believe that the country would have been much better off but where's the real proof to that? Of course, no one has the answer to that question but just look at the possibilities. Look at what JFK did between the years of 1961 and 1963 and look at the future. Think; "How would he have done that differently?" Anyway, Stephen King's 11/22/63 is a masterpiece. Although he is known to being the Godfather of Horror, I believe that this is his true masterpiece! My only criticism of the book is this; why did it have to end? Was an ending really necessary?

This is one of the best books that I have ever picked up! It has taken me a while to get through it, and I am almost finished with it now. I cannot wait to get home everyday from work to continue! Very good story. I will be sad when it is over.

I couldn't wait to read this book; the premise was fascinating! You get a little bit of everything with this book. . A little bit of suspense, a little bit of science fiction, of romance, of page turning anticipation, and unfortunately a little bit of fluff and disappointment. The ending was very anticlimactic and empty. Too much leading up to the event, then not enough after. It was just "okay" for me, Constant Reader.

This was one of the best novels I have read all year.  Definitely a slight change of pace for Mr. King, but I must say I loved it.  The characters were ones you easily fell in love with.  I even shed a few tears throughout the book.  I really loved the history and nostalgia of the story.  I will say, the book was quite long but was well worth it to develop the characters and story.  Again, I recommend this for anyone who wants to be transported back in time and want to enjoy a wonderful story.

I was a newly married, newly pregnant and fairly newly employed 24 year old on 11/22/63.  My major in college was history, so of course when I saw this was coming out I preordered on my kindle.  I was absolutely stunned with how King made the 50's and early 60's come alive.  I was reading it on my iPad as well as my kindle even though it is much easier on my eyes to read the eink.  I just couldn't put it down so when I had my iPad out to check email or something I couldn't resist going on the app (telling myself I'd just read a few pages rather than go upstairs to my bedroom to retrieve my Kindle)and of course then I was hooked.  I'm just in awe of King's talent and imagination and was really sorry when I finished the book.  I haven't read a lot of King, but I enjoyed Under the Dome, and liked 11/22/63 even more.  Worth every penny.

Reading a Stephen King book is an experience.  Now some critics might point out what happens in one of his books can never happen in real life.  And, to me, that's the point - he creates worlds and characters that will never, ever exist, but while you are reading they do exist.  His greatest gift is making the unbelievable, well.... believable.  I read a lot and, unfortunately, find a great many books that once started can easily be put down and ignored for a few days.  Not a King book.  I bought this book the day it came out and tried not to start reading it for 3 whole days because I had a big rescue animal fundraiser to get organized.  No luck - I started and read all night.  One other thing - while I love that he writes long, long, long stories I nearly dislocated a shoulder reading "Under the Dome" - so I was really glad I got a Kindle last Christmas, much easier to hold!

I'm new to this, and many others have given synopses and point by point comments.  I only know this... I have been reading Stephen King since Salem's Lot was published. To me, this book has the same quality as his earlier novels, and is easily one of his best.

I don't normally give 5-star reviews. In fact, I'm pretty hard on the authors I read. Even the great Stephen King has written some real duds in my opinion, but I'm pleased to tell you that 11-23-63 was storytelling at it's very best. There's a reason why it is a unanimous #1 best seller. Mr. King's style of writing has always been compelling but somewhere along the way he usually loses me. It's mostly as a result of pushing the limits of my imagination too far or overdosing on horror for horror's sake. I can suspend reality but only so much. But this is not a horror story in the traditional sense. In this book, even though the concept of a rabbit hole or rip in the fabric of time is completely fantastical, I didn't care. By the end of the book the way our protagonist Jake (George) moved between time was secondary to the missions he was trying to accomplish and even the most diehard theoretical physicist wouldn't question the science and would instead enjoy a very good story. It had just the right balance of action, mystery, romance and character development. Although there were a few holes and some better explanations were needed for the existence of some of the characters, like the yellow card man, this is simply Stephen King at his very best. Another minor nitpick I have is the drawn out ending. About halfway through the final chapter I was beginning to think it was a bit unnecessary, but then Mr. King wrapped it up perfectly. It's one of those rare works of fiction that ended in just the right way so as not to suggest a sequel. Stop reading reviews and just get the book. You will enjoy it if you keep an open mind.

I don't read much fiction; I probably should read the stuff more often. This book reminded me of what a pleasure it is to read a good yarn that causes you to keep turning the pages until sleepiness forces you to put it down for the night. I've never been much of a fan of the time-travel gimmick in story-telling, but King makes it work as well as could be expected in this story. His descriptions of 1958 and succeeding years ring true to my own recollections. Only a couple of anachronistic clunkers come to mind, such as having one of the characters from "the Land of Ago" talk about the Chicago Bears winning the "NFC" (there was only the "NFL" back then; the NFC and AFC were not created until the NFL-AFL merger of 1970.) King is excruciatingly detailed in describing physical injuries that people suffer as a result of accidents or assaults, perhaps drawing on his own experience of being run over by a motor vehicle. He always excels at the small details in his descriptions. I don't think his usual feel of authenticity quite comes through in his descriptions of love and sex scenes, which are fairly ordinary and predictable. I always have felt King is better at short stories and novellas than long works like this, but there's only a few spots where this one lags; this may be because the very nature of the storyline propels the book forward to its inevitable climax. Certainly I would recommend this to anyone looking for a fun read, especially anyone who - like me - has personal memories of 11-22-63 and all the speculation and conjecture that followed.

I don't normally read Stephen King novels.  However, I was intrigued by the idea.  Within a few pages, I was completely immersed.  Am only a third of the way through and find it captivating, smart, complex.  But what works best is characters with whom you can identify and for whom you care....deeply.

This was my first King novel and it exceeded my expectations. I've never read King as the horror genre doesn't interest me much. But the premise of this book sounded intriguing so I gave it a go. The novel wasn't anywhere near horror, I'd venture to say that it strikes close to a tale of romance. I never would've thought Stephen King could write romance, a fantastically riveting one at that.

Years ago when I worked the night shift, as tired as I was when I got home I always took the time to read at least 50 pages of the Stephen King book I was currently reading.  Then, for some reason I lost interest in the books.  Well, I do believe that this is what I have been looking for.  The "old" Stephen King.  I can not put it down and I am lovin every minute of reading it.  LT

I've read every Stephen King book. I'm a huge fan, clearly. Not all are great. Some, frankly, should have stayed in a drawer. When he is doing his best work, though, it's hard for me to find someone who is a better storyteller. And like any great author, occasionally a masterpiece lands. This is easily one of his best novels ever, which is saying it's one of our best novels. Understand, you could not pay me to read anything about the Kennedy Assassination. I avoided this book for months, then started it, then put it down after about 40 pages, because I couldn't work up the energy to read about 'Oswald and ghosts' to quote Woody Allen. Finally, months later, I picked it up again and made it a little farther. One particular event happened and I was sucked in. I then tore through the first two-thirds, I was so entranced, then went slow in the final third because I didn't want it to end. It's that damn good. And while it certainly deals with the assassination, it is about so much more! The characters are wonderful and real, you care about them deeply. Where the novel eventually winds and it's ultimate points are genuinely surprising and thought-provoking. I cried a number of times in the final sections and was deeply, deeply moved. If certain critics and award circles could get over their haughtiness about populist authors, this could be the book that wins King some top awards. He deserves it for this. It's that damn good.

I am a sucker for time travel. I have read most of the "must reads" for that genre, except the "Dark Tower" series by King. My son, a Stephen King fan, is enamored with DT, and has told me I "have" to read it, but he also loves "Memnoch the Devil" by Anne Rice, and I just couldn't get into that one, so I will just stick to what I know. Having said that I will admit that Stephen King's horror is often a bit much for me. I loved "Bag of Bones" until the horror kicked in, but I do love "The Girl Who Loved Tom Gordon" and "Green Mile", and cherish them as favorites. I eagerly anticipated the release of King's latest, a novel exploring time travel and the possibility of changing history on November 22, 1963, and felt that I could overlook the horror to get a dose of my favorite fantasy - time travel. I wasn't disappointed. Like many other reviewers on here, my productivity level dropped to zero while I was hungrily consuming this tale. I kept my Nook (sorry Amazon) with me at all times - in the laundry room, in the kitchen, at work at my desk, in my bed. Could this be harmonics? - my final pages coincided with a special about "The Lost Bullet", and one man's desire to know who fired that first shot, and what happened to it. As we were watching the re-enactments, John F. Kennedy, the First Lady, and Governor Connelly, were in the motorcade, traveling the streets of Dallas in time to the exact same thing I was reading! My heart was pounding during these final moments of Jake/George's harrowing attempt at changing the face of American history.  This book was long, but that was never a concern. I literally devoured the pages, while at the same time feeling sadness at approaching the end. To say I loved this book is an understatement. I can't wait for my husband to read it so that we can talk about it. I often just tell my husband the stories I read, as he's busy and not as much a reader as I am, but in this case, I want him to experience what I did. If you're on the fence about this book, or feel daunted by it's length, don't worry. Jump in! You will love everything about it - the nostalgia of life in the 50's and 60's, the wonderful characters that take up residence in your heart, and the easy-to-swallow history lesson that comes free!  My review title warns you to watch out for the "strings", and I can only say that you will understand that statement after you read it!  Enjoy!

What a stunner! King hits it out of the park with this one. This is king at his best. I read this one in 24 hours and could not put it down. Not only was it a great story with a cast of fascinating characters but it was also historically interesting. Many times I had to stop reading and google different things that caught my interest. This was not only fun to read but educational as well about a time and a place that many of us never experienced. I am the same age as the main character and I  grew up in Dallas. I grew up in the shadow of JR and the Kennedy assassination. I have been to the grassy knoll however it never was as real as it was in king's world. One thing I must say, King's judgement of Dallas is very typical to those whose visit to Dallas is brief. Having grown up there and lived in many other cities like New York and Los Angeles I can tell you that the people are a great deal warmer and kinder than he gives them credit for and many of us Southern democrats are under represented in his book but most New Englanders with a perfunctory knowledge of Dallas would be influenced more by what people think they know about the city and it's inhabitants than what it truly is. Despite this I truly enjoyed this one and you should immediately stop what you are doing, buy this book and don't expect to do anything else for the next few days.

Wonderful story. Makes you long for the "good old day's". Couldn't put it down, hated for it to end. And for us of the Kennedy and Nam generation it brings back lots of thoughts we probably buried for years.

Just finished reading this on my kindle, awesome book with great historical accuracy built in, the afterword notes the few things king changed to fit the storyline. I think this is my new favorite SK book.

First of all, kudos to Stephen King.  I dedicated all of two weeks in reading this captivating and suspenseful time-travel of a story.  And not was I disappointed.  I don't read many of these type of stories, but when Stephen King takes on time-travel and history, I pretty much trust with my gut he's going to deliver, which he has.  Within the mist of the chaos of trying to save one of America's historical people of that time period, there is also a beautiful and yet challenging romance between George Amberson/Jake Eppings and Sadie Dunhill.  For those who are future writers of any genre, who likes to add romance to their stories, Stephen King shows you how a great one should be written.  Sadie is my absolute favorite character from the moment she enters the story to the end.  She made laugh, cry, and root for her.  As for the story, in general, if you like a good food-for-thought thriller that will keep you on your toes I'd say read this.  Even if you don't read much Stephen King.  Even if you don't know much about JFK and his politics.  This book incredibly entertaining if nothing else.  I had a blast reading 11/22/63 and Stephen King truly applies all his creative magic to this story making it one of  his most splendid pieces of work he's ever done.

I really don't know what to say:  this was a great premise for a book; the "what if you could go back in time and save Kennedy, kill Hitler, stop Pearl Harbor, or whatever"  scenario.  In King's version, Jake Epping, a 35-year English teacher has the opportunity to go back in time and attempt to avert the Kennedy assignation.  Epping is introduced to the concept of time-traveling and the prospect of saving Kennedy by Al, the proprietor of a local diner.  Apparently there is a "rabbit-hole" in the pantry of the diner that deposits anyone climbing through to September 9, 1985 (always the same date).  Al asks Epping, a man whom he only knows as a customer, to "carry on his mission" since Al is now dying.  After thinking about this for precisely one day, Epping goes back in time and lives there for five years while he concocts a plan to stop Lee Harvey Oswald.  The story starts out well enough and then it just falls apart; it is a rambling, cliché ridden mess where the past is romanticized/sanitized and the protagonist develops amazing (read: unbelievable) skills (spying, shooting, planning) .  Great concept, lousy execution; this book would have benefited from a heavy editing hand, 300 less pages, and two less story lines.

One reviewer stated that this book is his best since Hearts In Atlantis. I have to agree. Hearts In Atlantis has been my favorite book of his and this one is certainly on a par. One of the things I enjoy doing after reading a book I enjoyed reading is to go back and read some of the reviews that weren't very kind to the book to contrast what they didn't like to what I did like. I read the few 1 star reviews and most of them were upset with with King for not making this a pure action book surrounding the plot of time travel to prevent the Kennedy assassination. That book would have ended up being just a pure Sci Fi book. A good one, and interesting, but not remarkable. Instead King has us travel back to the way things were in small town America for which he has an ongoing love affair. So do I... The love story between Jake and Sadie as well as the heroic characters of the townspeople from Jodie are beautiful and they give the story the depth of feeling and emotion I expect when I read the last sentence of a book. I want to feel something at the end and King has accomplished that here. It is a beautiful love story meshed with a Science Fiction premise but make no mistake, this IS a love story and a very good one at that!

With a novel such as 11/22/63, I fail to understand why some novice book reviewers, such as myself, wish to reveal the entire plot in a book review? In my opinion, one of the many joys of reading Stephen King is discovering the unknown, and what wonderful tricks SK has up his sleeve this go around. 11/22/63 is one of my favorites novels, from my all time favorite author, in several years! SK never fails to deliver and always keeps the reader awake until the wee hours of night, unable to put down the book, devouring each chapter like a fine chocolate truffle! Unlike some of Mr. King's other mammoth novels, the reader will be constantly in suspense, and eager for what is next, but not terrified and checking under the bed before finally turning off the bedside light to go to sleep.  I am a Kindle owner and love downloading books immediately, but some books must be owned and held in the reader's hand. This is one of them! If you are a fan of suspense, conspiracy theories, time travel, and the "What Ifs" in life, you will adore this book! Happy Reading fellow Stephen King Fans... and for those who have never ventured into Stephen King's world.. this book would be an excellent place to start. Namaste`

No, I'm not really a Stephen King fan.....don't read his books.  But the contents of this book intrigued me.  First, he goes back to my era....the 50's.  Second, I love anything about JFK.  Third, I love anything pertaining to time travel.  Fourth, the concept of changing history and the affects of it just fascinated me.  This is a really big book, literally, over 800 pages.  I bought the book because I had a gift certificate and if I was going to pay that much for a book I wanted the actual book not the Kindle version.  That all being said....since I'm so used to the Kindle, it was very hard for me to handle and hold this huge book.  I've been spoiled....just pushing a button...versus turning pages and holding......but, because this book was so interesting to me, I got through it and loved it.  Could not imagine how he was going to end this story, but in my humbler opinion, Mr. King did it well.  I'm a skimmer.  When I read a book and it goes. Into unnecessary and boring detail, I'll skim through.  I didn't do that with this book.  I'm still not a Stephen King fan.....this book will not make me want to read all of his other books....but I'm a little more open to the possibility now.

I was shopping one Saturday afternoon and passed this book in the book aisle and immediately did a double take. 11/23/63. The title gave away the book's premise and I was immediatley attracted to the time travel thing and the idea of going back in time to Dallas in November 1963 to thwart the Kennedy assassination. A lot of people probably don't have time to read a 845 page novel, but this book just draws the reader in like the time portal that is introduced to us about twenty pages into it. It's doubtful that a shorter version, trimmed by 300 pages, would have been as satisfying. Sounds like a cliche' but, literally, you won't be able to put this book down. I was doubly convinced that I had to read this book after listening to Stephen King himself being interview about this latest work of his on National Public Radio. He conveyed the premise of his novel with such intriguing detail. Years ago, upon finishing Larry McMurtney's western novel Lonesome Dove I actually felt sad to say goodbye to that story and its characters. I'm sure that I'm feel equally blue after finishing King's 11/23/63. Certain books are hard to say goodbye to. I highly recommend this book.

Since by now you will already know the premise of this book, and other reviewers have given good overviews, I won't bother with that here.  Instead, I will say that I truly believe that this is King's best work of his very prolific career.  I was a big fan of early Stephan King and his pseudonym Bachman, but stopped reading him about 10 years ago.  I felt that after his initial big successes, he sadly succumbed to "writer's popularity", churning out works "on schedule" to meet publisher and fan demands that sold merely because of his former successes.  However, I bought this book because the premise sounded so promising.  I'm so glad I did.  I quite literally could not put this book down.  In my opinion, King's earlier works were unmatched for suspense, yet his endings often left me disappointed.  I hoped that 11/22/63 would not be the same.  In this work, King has mastered it all.  His first foray into time travel has all the suspense of his earlier works and, although this is a very long book, never once did it drag. King has managed the enviable accomplishment of making every page a page-turner.  I found myself sorry to finish it.
One of my favorite King stories.  Well-written and the ending, while strange in typical King fashion, was satisfying.  If you like King, and Kennedy history, pick this one up.
THIS is the type of Stephen King I so enjoy. (not into horror) His reseach is tremendous and his character development is the best. You like all the characters. Great book. A+

I've always been fascinated with anything JFK related, so when I heard Stephen King was writing an alternate history book about JFK, I knew that I had to read it. I enjoyed the story. I loved the details of small-town life. When I read a book I like to feel like I've been everywhere the characters have been and have done everything they've done, I got that feeling with this book, and that made me happy. My only real complaint is one that I've had with several of King's books in the past. It was a little drawn out. This story certainly could've been told in less than 849 pages. The plot is not that complicated or detailed to necessitate over 800 pages. It's obviously told in so many pages because that's the way King chose to tell his story. I personally would've much rather have read the same story in 500 pages, which I think it could easily be edited down to. That's just my personal preference. It's obvious that many people love this book exactly as it is, but I grew a little weary of so many repetitious thoughts and actions that were not essential. I still thought it was a good read and enjoyed it very much.

Let me just say first this is a really long book! 842 pages in hard cover. And while part of me is slightly disappointed in this book, part of me loved it. I used to read a lot of Stephen King, and haven't read one of his books in years. I picked this one up because of the topic. I have wanted to read more about Kennedy and the assassination. While I know this is a Novel, and I didn't expect to learn any new facts about the assasination, when I think about the book from the Kennedy assassination stand point I kind of want to give this book 3 stars. I wanted a more indepth look at what the world would be like if Kennedy had lived.  The book did cover that, don't get me wrong.  I just wanted more of this.  So I found the book a bit disappointing from that stand point. But if I look at the book from a love story stand point, then I liked the book tremendously. I just didn't expect this book to be so much of a love story. From a love story stand point, this book was beautifully written, that's just not what I expected.  Overall, I liked the book quite a bit,this is one that will stay with me for some time.
I absolutely loved this story. Stephen King is a talented writer who makes you care about the characters. I did NOT want the book to end, and I'm actually sad that it did.
Read it. It will be worth your while. This book was a true source of entertainment for me. No matter how long it takes you to read, go for it, you won't be disappointed!

Stephen King's hero, Jake Epping, aka George Amberson, takes a trip "down the rabbit hole" to 1958 as a favor to his dying friend Al Templeton to change history by preventing the assassination of President John F Kennedy by Lee Harvey Oswald. He starts in 1958 because that is where the "rabbit hole" in the pantry of Al's diner takes him. Each time he returns to the present, he believes, is a "total reset" to the last outcome he created. Each time he goes, no matter how long he is gone, only two minutes have passed when he returns. These little details and King's wonderfully descriptive turns of a phrase bond the reader/listener to the story as Jake stays in the past in a count down to 11/22/63, the day Kennedy was shot. As he waits he meets the woman who will become the love of his life. Will she come back with him into the future? Will he succeed in stopping the assassination and create other changes he believes will improve the lives of others? Or is the quest he promised Al he would make more than he bargained for? Either way, you will be gripped by the journey!

Don't we all daydream about such things? What it would be like to go back in the past, just to see what things were like in your own neighborhood in another era--or perhaps to go back, to fix your most regretted mistake in life--or even to play hero and rescue the world from some historical disaster? This book delves into a world where such things are possible. But what are the consequences? If things go as planned, will the intended result of your heroism pan out? Will even mundane occurrences in your time-traveling adventures have unforeseen costs? 11/22/63 blends fact with fantasy in a way that you will experience with all the senses. I could not help but care so deeply about the characters as to be driven to tears at times, and many others have had the same experience with it. As wild as 'historical revisionist sci-fi' sounds, this book was fascinating, fun and deeply moving. I'm finally through all 849 pages and am sad just to have to leave the fantastic, nostalgic world of this story behind. A truly valuable, though heartbreaking, experience .

Being a loyal King fan is not a prerequisite to read and get caught up in a hell of a great ride that is this novel.  A great read should take you out of yourself where you totally identify with the characters and can't wait to know how the story comes out:  this novel delivers. I am always impressed with the richness of detail of the times and places King paints...I was swept away with Hearts In Atlantis, and that is the case with 11/22/63.  Bravo, Stephen King.  I was a young boy when Kennedy was killed, but I know where I was and what I was doing when it happened, as most Americans can attest who were alive for the event.  Thinking of what I knew and felt then is a journey through time and I feel the freshness and immediacy of the tragedy today. It's no wonder as the author points out that this novel couldn't have been written years ago when the emotional wounds were so fresh: it's time now is appropriate.  And if you were born after the assasination, this novel can fill in many feelings and events you might have missed...the story is that good.
It is quite long, but after finishing the story, I realized this was well worth it. Now I am reading other Stephen King novels. This was the best story I've read.

I always found Stephen King's earlier works TOO realistic in their depiction of horror. But with this, and Under the Dome, he's turned a corner for me. Although both are still graphic and contain violence, especially in this novel the violence is  essential to the story. This one made me almost glad I had a head cold and had to stay in bed, because I read the whole thing in about four days and actually put myself on page rations so I could savor it. Stephen King knows how to populate an entire town with characters that you either love or hate -- and he controls which outcome is which, because of his abililty to give each his or her own personality and language. Honestly, if there is a more gifted storyteller -- one who, after a horrific accident and a hardscrabble upbringing (read his On Writing, also a wonderful book and one that has changed the way I approach the written word; no more passive voice!) knows from whence he speaks regarding suffering -- I would like them to stand up and try to write SK under the table. Ain't gonna happen!

This book totally fascinated me and was a deeper story than I expected. It's probably the longest novel I've ever read and I am not a good reader, I tend to want to pronounce each word I read so for me to read a 853 page novel is a fete in itself and I'm glad I chose this one. I am just a year younger than Stephen King, so at first, it was nostalgic to read about the 50s and 60s time period. But the concepts King has about time travel itself, is very believable and something that has stayed with me and I've given a lot of thought. I, like many Americans, lived through the Kennedy Assassination when I was 14. It was the first time I sat up and started listening to our President. I'm sure his youth, humor and good looks had a lot to do with it. So the assassination was significantly tragic to me at the time and has stayed with me through the years.I wasn't disappointed by this story. King's character development is so well done that I actually started caring more about them than the assassination itself. I highly recommend this novel.

I have read many Stephen King books in the last 20 years or so. His imaginative story-telling tends to grab my attention. I get frustrated, though, when I've read some of my favorite authors for a while, then read a Stephen King book like 11/22/63 for a period of time. To me, the stories are always interesting - from his accounts of the setting to the character development. I always find myself on the emotional roller coaster of rooting for the hero or turning the pages quickly to see what will happen next. Nonetheless, I get very thrown off by his writing. Perhaps it is because he writes so many novels so quickly and to such a massive audience that he reverts to repetitive word use and over-simplified language over and over again. If I had to tally how many times he had written that the past is "obdurate" or that it "harmonizes," I'm certain I'd run out of loose leaf. Even when he was speaking in the voice of a well-educated man, he refers to a train as a choo-choo rather matter of factly. Should Mr. King or any of his circle ever read such reviews as this - PLEASE get back to that good ol' storytelling we knew so well without dumbing down the language...it's distracting!! Nonetheless, three cheers for an excellent story.

The only reason I'm giving this book 4 stars is because I'm only 350 out of 850 pages into it, so I guess I could end up being disappointed, but so far I've been totally transfixed.  I got to say, King as at the top of his game here.  Some of his scenes set in Derry that harken back to another of his novels set in Derry are kind of cheesy, but otherwise our return to Derry is well worth the time.  I've been reading King's works since I was 10-years old when I walked to the bookstore to buy a paperback copy of "Pet Semetery" because my mom forbid me to walk down to the movie theater to see the film version.  So I hate to admit that his novels over the last decade haven't gripped me as much as his novels from the 70's, 80's and 90's (with the grand exception of "Cell" as well as his collections of short stories and novellas).  "Under the Dome" was pretty good compared to "Bag of Bones" and "The Girl Who Loved Tom Gordon", but so far "11/22/63" has blown them all away.
Great story, really interesting subject.  Didn't expect there to be a love story also (made me cry a few times) - loved listening to it in the car -

I am a huge King fan and have read anything he ever wrote. No matter the story, he can bring characters to life like no other writer, and have you invested in a story and caring about the characters within the first few chapters.  That being said, this is the best book that SK has written in a long time.  I could not put it down.  I know that some people have written off Stephen King as a horror writer and can not get past the fantasy type stuff and the blood and gore that he seems to work into every book, but this book has a lot less of that than most of his writing and I think would appeal to any type of reader, even the ones who think they do not like Stephen King books.  It has so much of the personal connections and detailed characterization that I really think make SK stand out as one of the best writers of our time.  I just hope that this is a sign of more to come, and he can continue to produce books of this caliber until he is old and grey!

Love Stephen King, but this was b-o-r-i-n-g. It really should have been half as long. I think he wrote it for himself. You could obviously tell the time period, the politics, the music, etc. were special to him, but it made for tedious reading, in my view. There were several interesting sections, but they were short-lived. I missed the creepiness and trademark King style. Obviously this was a very different book. If you like historical fiction and don't mind reading endless details about the minutiae of day to day life in the late 50s-early 60s, you'd probably really enjoy it. The assassination of JFK and Oswald really took second place to the story of the main character meeting and falling in love with a woman in a small town. I enjoyed the time travel aspect of it, but that also seemed more of a background story that was just used as a tool to get the protagonist to that small town and the love interest.

11/22/63 is a new style for Mr. King, and I own nearly all of his books.  The human mind and body, similar to the story line in The Dome, is an amazing subject to read about. King is able to get into the head of everyone of his characters and take you on an incredible journey of what-ifs and what-abouts. 11/22 is also my birthday so I have a special connection with JFK, this book brings him back to us in a special way.  King continues to evolve and show us his deep emotional connection to his stories that he shares as only King does, by taking you inside each characters head and helping that video that we create be real and irresistible.  Bravo Stephen King, you never cease to amaze me, and for those who dont read King because it is too scary or dark, treat yourself to 11/22/63.  You will think about this book long after you have finished reading it, another 200 pages would have been just fine.

I have been a Stephen King fan since Salem's Lot but in the last few years have kind of fallen away. The concept of this book seemed interesting so I thought I would try again. I was hooked from the beginning. If I don't like the characters I won't read a book but I fell in love with these immediately.Although there isn't any traditional "horror" in the book there are supernatural elements. The book is about so much more than trying to go back and stop the Kennedy assassination though. It is about the changes that were coming to America in the early 60's. It is about the people and the attitudes, the nostalgia we have for those times now and the reality of those times, simpler times yes but not really more innocent times. It is (I think) about what we do or are willing to do for those we love, for better or worse....but at it's basic level it's a good story and a satisfying ride.

I really enjoyed Mr. King's newest novel.  I haven't read his books since his early novels.  But I thoroughly loved the time travel back to one of my passions in life - the JFK assisination.  Having been in 9th grade when that happened it's always been my "911"; I've read many many books on this particular subject; and though I do not agree with the lone killer being Oswald, like King does, I still found myself spellbound at times and it was one of those 'can't put down' books for me.  I love the love story that's wrapped inside this piece and was disappointed that it didn't turn out better in the end. Certainly made me think about not changing what has already happened; and like they say "everything happens for a reason".  All in all it's one of the best books I've read in a very long time... can't wait for the movie!  Thanks, Steven King, you're a genius!
S. K. You are the best! I could hardly put this book down. It kept me glued to the pages just like your Green Mile did. Thank you.

Just finished this epic and painstakingly researched new work from the great Stephen King. This is a must read for King fans and history buffs alike, and particularly so for any of us Texans, as a great deal of the drama takes place here in 1960-63. If you are not a King reader because you don't like horror, scifi, or gore- well, then this book is perfect for you because it has none of those trademark Stephen King markings. This is just an incredible novel about an average guy who stumbles upon an opportunity to go back in time and stop John F Kennedy's assassination. He embarks on this journey reluctantly because he is convinced it will change America's course for the better. Ultimately, he has a Stephen King style adventure in the vein of " The Stand" and even has an opportunity to experience deep and true love that endures the ravages of time.

There's nothing like a compelling Stephen King novel-a wild, mesmerizing, roller coaster ride. I used to be a huge fan as a teen and through my twenties. But then he changed-or perhaps I did-it all seemed too weird, too violent, too vulgar. So I stopped reading, and just reminisced of the good ole' books such as The Stand, Misery, The Shining, the excellent short stories such as Shawshank Redemption, The Body,(inspiration for the movie Stand By Me), to name a few. Well, with 11/22/63, the old Steve is back! An incredible, clever story exploring what could happen if you could time travel and change history-in this case stop Lee Harvey Oswald from shooting JFK. A classic King book as much of the action is in small town Maine, and many references to past King books. And a love story, for a change. Fun read, historically thought provoking.

I LOVED this book, I LOVE SK. I didn't want it to end. It's not traditional SK, but it does include a little whisper of his younger self. This was different and it shows that SK possesses a wide range of talent. This book provoked so many different emotions for me. You can't help but love a book that can do that. For those that gave this book a 1 or 2 star rating and are so passionately criticizing SK for this book, which in my estimation, shows his evolution as a writer.  They want traditional SK, they want the bejeezuz scared out of them. That didn't necessarily happen here. The criticism comes because these people here hate change. He's evolving and these so-called "fans" can't handle it. I love the fact that SK is capable of change. Most writers just dry up. I hope SK never stops writing. I am intently looking forward to his next.

Very disappointing from such a talented author. The novel starts with such promise and then dissolves into a boring drawn out overly detailed account of mundane events. I eventually had to speed read through large parts of the book (another play, another dance, another drawn out conversation with no relevance) just to get to the parts of the plot that were relevant. And plot flaws abound. A man so worried about the butterfly effect but waits years to do the one deed he wants to do at the last possible second meanwhile affecting the lives of so many. Even if he only changed the one thing he came to do, it would have probably resulted in everyone he knew in the present not ever being born. Even himself. I expected so much more thought provoking plot and much less trivial page-filling fluff. Where have you gone Mr. king?

I've been a S.K fan for a while.  I will say if you are familiar with his work (especially if you enjoy the Dark Tower series) you will probably enjoy this one.  I read all 850 pages in three days.  It deals with time travel in a unique way and it is a fascinating and somewhat educational concept.  Like all of King's novels, he takes his time to get to the meat of things.  But every chapter had me on the edge of my seat.  I highly recommend this to SK fans.  For those of you who are not that familiar with King's writing be aware that he likes to bend reality.  Usually he is the "master of horror." This book, though there are elements of horror, is more of a thriller/mystery.  It's written very well and though it's quite a hefty book, the read is easy (the cliff-hanger chapters are short).  I hope you enjoy the book.

Everything about this novel hits the nail on the head for me. Well thought out characters, a story that could become cliche but manages to transcend, an ending that is not a crowd pleaser but makes a whole lot more sense then a possible happily ever after. While I see some complaining about the length of pacing of this book, they obviously are more likely to read the destroyer of American words books, James Patterson, then an actual important member of the American ouevre. Looking at King's book, the greats to me or the door stoppers, "It", "The Stand", "Needful Things"-give King the ability to write beyond 400 pages and you've got a masterpiece on your hands in my opinion. Having to pick what some would say is not what actually happened on that day in November would to some be a weakness but for me is a strength, I'm now committed to the idea that Oswald did it, indicating how strong King's writing is. Overall a highly recommended book for anyone who likes fiction and time travel.

When "Under the Dome" came out, I had really been excited to read it ... and ended up enjoying it but was disappointed. When "11/22/63" was announced, the premise did not really appeal to me, I must admit. I didn't want to read a political time travel thriller, but I purchased it anyway, as I'm a huge King fan. Boy, was I blown away! This novel, with its great first person narration and almost Dickensian prose, is amazing, the best King has written in years. And I don't think it's just that my expectations were low. This novel is wonderful. From the fast-paced opening chapters, where our hero descends from 2011 back to 1958, through the wonderful Derry circa 1958 sequences (including surprising and exciting references to, and even two cameos from, IT, my favourite all-time King), on to Texas, and the main action, this is a compelling, unputdownable tour-de-force that manages to be exciting, haunting, enjoyable, and thought-provoking. I've just now finished it and may come back to add more to this review once I allow my thoughts to settle a little more. But suffice it to say, this is now one of my favourite Kings. Very highly recommended.

As someone who still remembers what life in the 1950s was like, who can say exactly what he was doing when he heard the news that President Kennedy had been shot, and who devoured tons of books about the various theories regarding the assassination in the years that followed, I couldn't resist this book and found it to be a great read.  I have enjoyed a number of Stephen King books in the past but in my opinion this is his best work.  The book has some very interesting ideas about the paradoxes of going back in time, a lot of fascinating research about Lee Harvey Oswald and the Kennedy assassination, a strong romantic interest, and a moving portrait of life in the 1950s, with both its good and bad sides. It's a big book and not easy to put down, so be prepared for some long nights!

I gave this book a five star rating without finishing it.  I simply do not want this book to end.  I am thoroughly enjoying reading it!  I'm a social studies teacher, so I was intrigued by the topic from the start.  I appreciated all the research he did in bringing this story to life. I won't go into a synopsis ~ lot of good ones here. My review is more about the experience of reading this book. I have read many of Stephen King's books, but I haven't in a while, so it was so nice to hear his "voice" again. I found myself dogearing pages simply because of his prose. I'm here hoping to find another one of his books that will willingly suck me into one of his worlds. If I can't find something today, maybe I'll read the Talisman for the third time.

I'm don't like horror at all, but I am always amazed by King's story-telling talents, on the non-horror type books.  11/22/63 is simply amazing.  Dont be scared of the length.  I never would have made it through if not worthwhile.  He really is the master of story telling, and this one is in line with "Stand By Me" and "Shawshank".  Continual sense of supernatural forces at work, but not gross or graphic at all...Great characters and he makes the time travel issues work.  Could have trimmed the middle a bit, (very little bit) as to the surveillance of Oswald, but thats really nitpicking.  Someday, somewhere (probably in Maine) King's works will be taught as amazing literature, rather than the perception that it is "airport reading" pop fiction.

Okay, "Under the Dome" was just an aberration, then. Stephen King is back and this babyboomer is very glad. Was in 4th grade when the announcement came over the loudspeaker that the president had been shot. Was watching TV alone in the upstairs "TV room" when Oswald was shot. Spent more of my adolescence watching famous assassinations and funerals alone and wondering when the nightmare would be over. Pages 615-616. Check it out and then say the book is "fluff." "Harmonic chords?" I'm just glad to know what to call them. "The past is obdurate?" Hell, yes. Been there, seen that, my whole life and not just on TV. Thank you, SK. Congratulations on the granddaughter and I hope she experiences little chaos and few storms during her life.

This one was really hard to put down.  SK has been on a real winning streak lately with some of the best work of his long career with two excellent collections (JUST AFTER SUNSET, FULL DARK,NO STARS) a terrific novella (BLOCKADE BILLY) and his epic UNDER THE DOME.  11/22/63 is really the icing on the cake.  11/22/63 is one of his most well written novels, ranking right up there with DOLORES CLAIBORNE and HEARTS IN ATLANTIS.  There are plenty of memorable characters and plot twists that King readers have come to expect, but there is something more restrained, mature and subdued about this novel and I think Mr. King's genious has never been more apparent.  If this one dosen't get him a Pulitzer nothing will.  The book really tugs at the heartstrings and, unlike the protaganist of this novel, I had tears in my eyes several times.  It's one of his best and King readers should be pleased.  I know you will have a fun time with all of the clever inside jokes and meeting up with some old friends from the town of Derry.  And do yourself a favor.  Buy the physical book.  This one is worth passing along to your kids someday (something you won't be able to do with a certain to be obsolete electronic book version).

I have to thank Stephan King for a wonderful weekend.  It's been a long time since I enjoyed a book so much.  I think I would have been even happier had he added another few hundred pages and flushed out the apocalyptic end-times scenario.  The ending was gripping, but all too brief and a little difficult to fathom. (Like, how exactly were natural disasters brought about by the interference of the main character in 1963?)  The best time travel book I've ever read.  In the Afterword, King recommends Jack Finney's Time and Again, which he says is the best time travel book he's ever read.  Sadly, it seems that the book is out of print.  I'm hoping some kind publisher makes the book available on Kindle.

Steven King has outdone himself and all of his previous works - although they were great.  When I read the concept for this book, having been in my late teens in 1963, I thought there was no way anyone could do justice to the concept.  How could I have doubted Steven King?!?!?!  His ability to make ever the most impossible and impalusible of everything seem possible is demonstrated in this book more than in all of his other work.  What a wonderful book.  Don't plan to accomplish anything other than read once you start.  Impossible to put down.  This book is a MUST READ for anyone who remembers that day, 11/22/63, and for everyone else it will be a quasi history lesson, fun read, and a challenge!

I am always leery whenever a book contains as many pages as this, especially from an author known for the totally bizarre.  Do not be afraid.  11/22/63 is a smoothly flowing, character centered, fantasy with a realistic tone and satisfying ending that exceeded my expectations.  I have seen criticism that the book is too heavy on details of the characters' lives.  Could it have been shortened? Yes. Should it have been? Absolutely not. These details and the stories within stories make it such an enjoyable read.  I was able to put it down, but couldn't wait to pick it up again.  Hurry though, Christmas is almost here and it would make a great gift for a reader on your list.  Or just treat yourself.

If you've read the description, you understand the premise: An average guy has the opportunity to change a significant moment in history...but history doesn't want to be changed.  The writing style seems to me to be typical King.  The story is interesting, as alternate histories can be, and reasonably well-paced.  There are a few fun, non-distracting references to his other stories, as he considers most (if not all) of them to be part of the same multi-verse.  I'm not always a fan of King's endings (let's say 50/50; and while he'd probably say they're all just "ka," I think he sometimes enjoys leaving the reader as uncomfortable at the end as in the middle), but this one was satisfying.

While it's best to review something many days after you've consumed it, I had to wait a few weeks for this one. This book and the impact of its storytelling is rivaled only by few other great works in American literature. I hadn't been able to sleep well since finishing it, King has ways of really taking over part of your brain. And while it's just fine with me, this book really inspires and gets my motor running in more ways than I had ever thought. Sure, it's long. Boo-hoo. Read this, absorb it, take a shower with this book, it's so great. I can't wait for the Hulu series based on 11/22/63, as other dimensions will be likely filled in from this epic. -Andrew Flynn, December 12, 2014.

This is my first Stephen King book and by god, I am hooked. As other reviewers had already mentioned, I at first wasn't too keen about the book when I read the premise, but then I tried reading the first page...and then 10 pages go by and then I found myself completely pulled in by the story and especially drawn to the main character. This was such an experience to read. The book being so long made it all the more involving.
