By the time I reached the last page, I was awed by the fact that I had actually finished a book I had thought would take me forever to get through; and I finished with a new-found hunger for more of Stephen King's work. Colorado Kid is on my list next.

I, like many folks who have been fascinated by the JFK assasination, was anxious to read how Mr. King would create a tale based on time travel.  About one third of the way through, I foound myself much more interested in the relationship of our hero Jake and his new found love, Sadie.  It really didn't seem to matter whether Oswald was thwarted or not, only whether Jake and Sadie would stay together and live happily ever after.  The end was truly agonizing for those of us routing for true  love to win out in the end.  Poor Jake reminded me soo much of the Gunslinger, so close yet so far from his deepest desire. Mr. King get better with age, a worthy follow up to The Dome.

My first thought was, oh no, not another 800+ page book! Then, oh no, not politics. Well this is one of my issues - judging a book by its cover. Well, I opened it up and was hooked from the get go. I should have realized that Mr. King wasn't out to disappoint me. The book was long, yes . . . but it had a story that pulled me through. I couldn't wait to pick it up every day. And I was sad to see it go. Without giving anything away, the book develops into a love story with the thread of what you read about on the jacket drawing the main character ever toward his goal. I felt for him. I nearly cried. I believe the book rounds out to a believable and enjoyable ending.

I had broken up with Stephen King years ago.  In the beginning - all those years ago - I read every book he wrote, but along the way he became too gruesome for my taste.  However, the hypothesis of this book was very intriguing and I couldn't resist.  At 800+ pages, it was too long to borrow from the library, so I bought it and took my time reading it.  It was well worth the investment in time and money.  I was a young woman in Fort Worth, Texas in 1963.  This “novel” was full of interesting bits of actual history and told of many events surrounding the assassination that I never heard reported by news media.  A good read – entertaining as well in informative.

I was an avid King fan in his early years, with Salem's Lot and The Stand my favorites.  I have read many of his novels since that time.  His writing style can never be faulted.  But his themes, protagonists, and endings were somewhat disappointing for me.  I recently enjoyed Under the Dome, but still felt a lack of maturity in his exploration of human relationships.  With this book, King has written two beautiful, mature, love stories.  One is between Jake and  Sadie.  The other is between the author and America - both that of the 50's/60's and the present. Both are heartfelt by both writer and reader.  Even after 900 pages, I did not want the book to end. Jake is the first King character who ever made me cry - even if he had a hard time with that himself.

I can't understand the outstanding reviews for this book.  Chacun a son gout, I suppose, but I just couldn't finish it, either on audible or on kindle.  King pounds us over the head with details of life in the 50's; it's like reading a travelogue written by a completely naive visitor to a land with which readers are already well familiar.  The plot crept along at a slow pace.  I could care about the main characters who were poorly fleshed out.  I quit one fourth of the way through.  I did read the last few chapters though, to see what happened, so I suppose I got a little curious.  I was SO grateful that I hadn't gone through the entire 800+ pages.

I love Stephen King's early works, then he seemed to just get off track to me. Not any more.  Thank you Mr King.  I just loved this book and read all 800+ pages in 4 days. Not a true horror story, but an intriguing time travel novel. Who wouldn't love to go back and just change one little thing, maybe two? There are twists and turns, subtexts and plots, all fascinating to me who lived through this era. I was 10 years old when JFK was shot and remember the people in my neighborhood running down the streets sobbing and screaming in fear and sorrow. (No, I didn't live in Dallas) 1958... isn't that the same year Christine came rolling out of Detroit?

I found myself skimming the last chapters of the book.....I had had enough. But what was most annoying were the many goofs and bloopers, and expressions that would not have been used in the 50's.  I found it hard to believe that young people were doing the Lindy Hop to Glenn Miller in 1958. "Wings of a Dove" on the radio before the song was actually written.  Jim LaDue tells Coslaw "You Rock!"  Someone needs to "Man Up".  People listening to "Louie Louie" in 1961. ( a 1963 song).  Also..the way that everyone speaks the same way.  Words constantly stream from the characters' mouths in a sort of clever, snappy patter.  Everyone ....Al, old ladies, bartenders, salesmen, little kids.  I was so glad when it was over.

11/23/63 captivated me from the first page and the ending was a knockout. I been a Stephen King fan for a number of years and big history buff even longer. It was great to read a book that so expertly wove a spelling-binding plot, great characters, and the cultural and political history of the late fifties and early sixties together. As I read, I kept speculating on how history would have unfolded if JFK had not been tragically assassinated and developed my own guesses. Well, all I can say is that the final chapters made the read all the more worthwhile. This Stephen King novel was both thrilling and thought-provoking at once.

I have read the majority of Stephen King's novels, but this is by far one of his best.  From the first chapter, the book pulls you in, and if you think it is predictable - think again.  The book is a story in a story, and you do not have to be a JFK junkie to enjoy it.  The fact is, I enjoyed the parts of the book that had nothing to do with JFK and the story behind the assasination, the best.  Unlike most King novels, there are no real horrors or supernatural occurances - just the scientific confusion associated with time travel.  King will have a difficult time surpassing this one.  I recommend it highly!

I haven't read any of Stephen Kings usual books, because every attempt made me put them down - the gore just isn't for me. However, due to the premise of this book, I picked it up and read it in 2 days! It's interesting, a good read, doesn't get into the usual theories of the Kennedy assassination. The reason I gave it 4 instead 5 stars is that the ending did not play for me - it was getting into the scary/gory/don't want to know details, which I associate with 'typical' King stories. Also, I agree with the assessment of Dallas - don't like it, it has a dark vibe. I'm going to try another S.K. book, soon!

This is definitely one of Stephen King's best books.  Even though we associate King with horror, this story is not of that genre.  It is basically a love story between a man from the 21st century and a woman from the mid twentieth century.  The JFK story about stopping the assassination, though definitely interesting, is not the main focus of the story.  This is a gentle story that takes place mostly in the "innocent" 1950's and early 60's.  It also discusses what happens to the future when we change the past.  The story and quality of writing were so good, that I literally couldn't put this book down!!

I just finished 11/22 and have to recommend it, especially if you are not normally a King fan. I hate horror books (i am such a wuss i get nightmares easily). But Stephen King's superior writing style, imagination, diction, imagery, characters, and ability to weave rich and intricate detail into his stories always has me on the prowl for one of his non horror books (if you're like this, also check out Eyes of the Dragon, another of my fave King novels). This one was fabulous and i devoured it in a few days. Fantastic read. Loved the allusion to harmonizing which refers to another of his stories ;-)

This is the first and only Stephen King book I have ever read for various reasons but his appearance on The Today Show and the ensuing discussion piqued my interest so I decided to give it a try.  I was NOT disappointed.  The book is lengthy, 840 pages?, but it's a fast read, almost conversational.  Since finishing it I haven't been able to put it out of my mind.  I keep mulling all the possibilities.  Thought provoking?  Check.  Entertaining?  Check.  Will it be made into a movie?  Almost certainly and I'll be disappointed if it isn't given justice.  The book and Mr. King deserve it.  Seriously.

I just finished reading this yesterday, and right now I'm still recovering. It's a fast paced book that is nearly impossible to put down, and is gut wrenchingly emotional. Not because of the Kennedy assassination itself, but because of the personal relationships that are developed throughout the story. The time travel aspect was of particular interest to me, and King handles it beautifully. I strongly urge you to get this book, but if you are like me and buy the Kindle version, you will find yourself reading this book at every spare moment you have (in bed, while cooking, on the subway, etc, etc).

I've enjoyed Stephen King's work immensely in the past, especially works like "The Girl Who Loved Tom Gordon" and "Delores Claiborne", but wow!  "11/22/63" kept me on the edge of my seat to the point I almost called in sick to work one day to keep reading.  I couldn't wait to find out what happened next.  This book has all the action, suspense, and yes, romance of ANY great book you'd ever want to read but without some of the over-the-top gruesome horror that sometimes makes me lose interest in other books.  You will not be disappointed and you will root for Jake over and over and over again!

What a sweet and tender book this turned out to be! It wasn't at all what I expected and has more in common with THE GREEN MILE than CUJO. I won't rehash the plot since so many have done so but I will say it ended up reminding me of the book TIME AND AGAIN by Jack Finney and the movies TIME AFTER TIME and SOMEWHERE IN TIME. I made it a multi-media experience by pulling up Glenn Miller's audio of IN THE MOOD during a couple of crucial moments in the book, including the end, and that made me even more teary-eyed than I already was. Bravo, Mr. King! You've created another classic!

This book, from the beginning, poses to you a question that so many people have probably asked themselves, would you change the past if you could?  And the one moment in time that you may think of is the Kennedy Assasination in 1963.  King presents characters to us that are so believable and relationships that are the central theme of the book.  Sure it involves time travel, but it brings you back to the late 1950's and into the early sixties, a time long gone by but described wonderfully here.  Was Oswald the lone assasin, and how would the world be different if Kennedy was not killed?  Great questions, and a great story in this book.  Read it, it simply Great!!

As always Mr. King spins a good yarn. Even when some of his plots wrap up in odd and sudden ways (and this is not one of those) his books are always an enjoyable read. Here he takes the reader back in time and does a magnificent job of making one feel what time travel to an earlier period must feel like. Much about the past is good and nostalgic and simpler and better, but the past has a dark side as well. A very interesting "what if" scenario that plays out logically and satisfactorily. The ending even made me choke up and shed a few tears. Well done.

This novel absolutely consumed me. I'm sitting here with tears rolling down my face from the ending; tears with all kinds of different emotions behind them. The cleverness of the plot is just the starting point of why this book is so good. The characters are very relatable I feel like I know them (which makes it even more heart-poundingly nerve-wracking right up until the very end). It's Sci-fi & historical fiction mashed together in a completely harmonious way. I'm so sad it's over because it will be a while before I find a book compares to this one!

Many people hear the name Stephen King and automaticly think vampires and werewolves etc. Sure, he has delved into those subjects but his best (in my opinion)works were not of that ilk. Shawshank, The Body (Stand By Me) were his best works. I would also put The Stand in this group. Actually The Stand is my all time favorite. Such great storytelling and character development. I feel 11/22/63 lives up to these standards. As far as I know I have read pretty much everything he has ever published and I would put this in my top 5 SK list no questions asked.

I thoroughly enjoyed this book! I hadn't read a King book in almost 20 years and thought he really hit it out of the park with this one. I also never had much interest in the Kennedy assassination but this peaked my interest. He really did a great job with a story line in two different eras in American history. I highly recommend this book to anyone. Some of my friends have mentioned not being able to stomach Stephen King stories due to the horror but there's none of that here, just a great time travel story with great twists and turns along the way.

I am not a fan of Stephen King, but I needed something to read on a flight, and 11/22/63 just stood out to me at the airport bookstore. It was not a novel that I couldn't put down, which I actually enjoyed. The book moved along at a great pace, and the character development was excellent. This was a truly enjoyable read, and I was impressed. I love that King places his story right on top of the pages of history and includes actual historical facts and accuracy in the story. It was a great mix of love, history, action, and just plain story-telling.

I started reading Stephen King about the time I learned to read (not really but it seems like that long ago)The first books I really enjoyed The Stand being my all time favorite.The last few books were kind of crazier than the early ones and I quit reading them until a friend suggested 11/22/63.I read 800 plus pages in less than a week and enjoyed every page.I have never been a big fan of time travel and mostly read James Patterson or Nicholas Sparks type of books.But if Stephen Kings books are like this one I am back to being a fan!!

Another winner from Stephen King that leaves you thinking long after you have finished the book.  If you could go back in time and change something that you thought would make the world better, would you?  It is a great premise and while the answer is not what you'd expect, I wonder if we applied it to 09/11/01, would you do it?  I think I might, but then we never know the consequences of different actions.  If string theory is a fact, this book is a powerful argument for pausing to reflect before deciding, even in theory.

King picked the low-hanging fruit and avoided controversy, cited one of the most debunked and discredited "authorities" as his #1 resource for "facts" about the Kennedy assasination and crafted a long but consistently engaging story around it. Nice work of fiction but it would have been truly inspirational if a mind as fertile as his would have left the ages something more than this about "our 9/11." He was certainly capable of it; it's a shame he turned away from the abyss and left a message saying that it isn't there.

Stephen King is once again able to tell an amazing story that leaves its mark on you well after you have finished reading.  He has a way of bringing his characters to life and making you sympathize with them. I love how he blends in pieces from previous books - in this case It.  I thought this was King back at his best form, which I was glad to see since I thought The Dome was a bit of a disappointment.  This is a must-read for all Stephen King enthusiasts. Can't wait till his next book comes out - when will that be?

This is a great read and Stephen King at his best. If you think of King as a guy who only writes horror books, forgetboutit! I personally think this is the best book he has ever written. This is the story of a school teacher who goes back in time to try and save JFK. The book is about 1000 pages long, and I wish it was 2000 pages, it is that good. King does a great job of capturing the 60s and the chaos in and around Dallas. If you are looking for a great book for yourself or to give to a friend, look no further.

I am not a fan of horror novels and have never read a Stephen King book before.  My husband loved the book and recommended it to me and I'm glad I listened (this time  ;-).  He builds up a very believable picture of the time period and what it might be like to be transported back there from the 21st century.  It got a little far out there at the end....but hey, the whole premise is far out so I'll give him that point.  You might have to be at least 40 to appreciate this - but if you are, I think you'll like it.

I've never read anything by Stephen King before, but I couldn't resist the title--my generation's 9/11. He took me back to the time that made me, conceived of a quest which, if it were possible, I'd sign up for in a heartbeat, reminded me that high ideals don't always produce good outcomes, and then reassured me that even if I can't change the world, living according to my ideals and treating the people around me with decency is sufficient. Not a bad message for us boomers as that good night looms ever nearer.

Simply put, this is one of the best books I have ever read.  I loved the story, I loved the main characters (especially Jake and Sadie) and I loved the journey. I truly savored every moment of this wonderful and completely engrossing story. And I am simply in awe of Stephen King's writing ability and his imagination. This is one of those books that you think about for a long time after you've read the last word. In fact, I think it has ruined me for reading anything else for a while. Very highly recommended!

Finally, Stephen King writes a book that doesn't make you lock the doors or look under the bed.  This was such a great read that when I got done I nearly flipped to the front and started reading it again.  It seemed in some parts that it would be predictable but thats when King revved it up and grabbed another gear.  The detail was incredible and it flowed like clear as a mountain river.  Not many authors dare touch on the subjects in this book, but we all know that there is only one Stephen King. Epic.

This book is perhaps the best book that Stephen King has written in a long time.  He managed to weave the actual events of the time period into the fictional story that makes the reader actual begin to identify with the story line and believe that this actually could be possible.  The description of the towns is extremely accurate as I live in Maine and am familiar with the locations.  His protrayal of the characters makes relating to them easy and we grow to love all of them.  It is just a great book!!

I just finished reading 11/22/63 and loved every word of the book.  Yep, every word.  This is one of those books one reads then is disappointed the story is over.  I know that when I see someone reading the book, I'll be envious they're reading it for the first time.  I love time paradox books, always have.  IMO, this is among the best of that genre.  I'm not going to give the plot, this isn't a book report, this is a personal/unprofessional review.  Do yourselves a favor.  Get this book on a Friday, free up your weekend, stock up on snacks and finger food and read from start to finish.  Mr. King?  If you read these reviews at all, thank you.  I've been hoping you'd write a time novel and you didn't disappoint.

The one thing I love about King's huge books is the way he allows you to lose yourself in his world.  Whatever world it is.  In this case, it's the fascinating idea of a person from our time traveling back in time and immersing himself in the late 50s/early 60s.  It's not always fast moving and action packed, but that's what I like about it.  The premise is intriguing and you find yourself wanting to find out what happens next.  And if nothing happens, that's ok too.  It's all about the journey.

I've never been a Stephen King fan but the subject matter of this novel intrigued me.  Having been married in 1958 I was very familiar with the time period he describes so perfectly, and of course, the Kennedy assassination was a huge event in my life.  I never expected to become so involved with the characters in this novel and was surprised at the number of times I was brought to tears by the emotions and situations described.  This is NOT the usual frightening, horror novel I expected from Stephen King.  It is a work of art and of history!  BRAVO!

I have been both deeply thrilled and as equally disappointed by King over the years. However, 11/22/63 just blew me away. This book is well written, and one who has studied the Kennedy assisination at length (and no, I am not a conspiracy theory wantabe) King has woven fact with fiction as well as I have ever read. The ending gave me the chills and I only hope when they make the movie (and someone will) I can only hope they are as faithful to the story as the care asking out into it,

11/22/63 has Steven King's usual page turning writing and an interesting idea with nice touches of the historical novel thrown in. However the constraints of historical fact trip him in the end. The necessary resolution of the story is spoiled with an unimaginative finish and the consequences of a somewhat confused understanding of the Butterfly Effect that has interference in human history prompting geological consequences. Good enough for a plane ride, but no better than that.

This is my first review post...ever!  I have not read a Stephen King novel in 20 years. Bought this a year ago and just started to read it.  As I was reading, I told friends how much I was enjoying it and hope he did not take a turn on me!  I was not disappointed one bit! The story capitivated me.  I was so pleased with the entire story.  I have recommended the book to many in just the week I finshed it.  I don't think anyone could not like it.  Like I said....my first review!

Vintage King... and that's as good as it gets. Not difficult to buy into the  time travel premise which sets the stage for all types of Butterfly effect possibilities. However, this is merely a back drop to one of the most wonderful and heart warming love stories you will ever read...and certainly not predicted or anticipated by the title. The ending is both satisfying and memorable and will linger in your heart far beyond the historical account of a sad time not so long ago.

It was excruciating to read this book, and I found practically nothing interesting, original in the story, in fact, there are too many holes, and non sensical turns that just cannot be materialized in a coherent manner. The writing style is boring and so long, there is no incentive to go on other than the fact that I am usually incapable of giving up on a book.  I have always wanted to read at least one by this prolific author, and I think I probably picked a wrong one.

I have been a King fan for 20 years and have read most of his books.  Some of which are my favorites (The Stand, Dark Tower).  I have to say this is one of his best and one of the best stores I have ever read.  Great writing, characters so real you think you knew them in real life, great twists and turns and a satisfying ending.  King seems to be finding his groove again which is awesome.  Can't wait for the next novel Mr. King.  This one was a real pleasure to read!

I haven't read every novel that King has written, but out of all the ones I have, I think this is his best by far.  The plot is intricate, the characters are ones we come to care a great deal about, and it's a page-turner in the best sense of the word.  It's ironic, but I think King's best work are those novels and stories where he dials down the supernatural and concentrates on the human condition.  He has obviously gotten better with age, and 11/22/63 is truly not to be missed, even by non-fans.  Very impressive.

I had given up on Stephen King years ago - I enjoyed Misery, Needful Things and others but recently didn't like his newer works.  WOW!  11/22/63 was fantastic!  Very interesting premise and very well researched and told.  I was a little freaked out to see some characters from 'It' appear (that book STILL gives me the willies after 15 years!).  I've recommended this book to many family and friends.  Would definitely recommend to Stephen King fans AND JFK buffs!

This is the best Stephen King book that I have ever read.  I used to think that after King became a successful writer, he wouldn't allow anyone to edit his books anymore and that they were too long.  But I recently read the unedited version of "The Stand" - well over 1000 pages long, and there was nothing there that I would remove.  This one is over 850 pages of great writing. It contains time warps, history, a love story, suspense, heartache, and a lot of Texas and Maine.  It would make a great movie.

Though it drags in spots, "11/22/63" is one of Mr. King's best. He's obviously taken up dancing as a hobby (therapy?) as it figures heavily in the tale. As to preventing Mr. Kennedy's assasination? Good idea? Leave well enough alone? To quote Mr. King himself from "Pet Semetary", hilariously mouthed by Fred (Herman Munster) Gwinne in the really bad film version: "Sometimes dead is better." One of his best, it drew tears at the end. You rock, Steve-O!

Can you believe it?!? A love story. Being a product of the era featured, I was truly impressed by all the little things which were right, on cue, subtly real. This a Must Read. Several of my friends said the ending made them bawl (or as one said, "made me bawl my eyes out"). My version was the audio CD, and it was so, so well done. But I still can't help but think my version (audio) of the ending outdid the text version. This story was phenomenal!

Stephen King can write!  Anyone who says different simply cannot recognize what good writing is all about.  That is, it's about characters.  No one creates characters like SK.11/22/63 is long, but good long books are like friends: you enjoy their company and when you have to part, you are reluctant to do so. The research, is pretty darn good too!  You are transported back, like Jake, and you are called to witness what 48 to 50 years really means.

I can't recommend this book highly enough. It contains all the trappings of great fiction - suspense, danger, love, the possible end of everything. Written in first person, it's witty and full of great nostalgic bits from the late 50's - early 60's. If you had to take just one book to a desert island with you, take this. I only had it for a week from the library but I'm going to buy it. Too good not to take off the shelf and just open and read.

This novel is excelent, you will be catched from the first pages until the end. One thing I didn't like is that since the author has to tell a story of several years, there are time jumps which could have resulted in very nice (sub)stories like the ones that were actually written. I understand that is impossible to describe every single day of a 10 years time span though, but when you are reading this novel, you would like it to be possible.

This is not your typical Stephen King novel. It is a wonderfully written story of time travel, but also one of the greatest love stories I have ever read. It was not at all what I expected, and definitely not something I could expect from Mr. King. I absolutely recommend this to everyone, even those who typically do not enjoy Stephen King's horror novels. You might find yourself completely immersed in one of the best stories ever written.

I give Stephen King huge kudos.  I haven't enjoyed a book like this in I don't know how long.  I have had to ration my reading so I don't finish it too quickly.  I love the concept of time travel and I love revisiting my childhood memories.  I was nine when President Kennedy was assasinated and remember that day vividly.  I can't normally read Stephen Kings work, because it creeps me out too much, but this has been a treat to read.

I have read everything by Stephen King and love most...but I can objectively say this is completely un King Like. t is a love story, no horror involved and I am not one to cry but a got emotional at the last 10 pages. I lik to read but 800 plus pages is an undertaking and I couldnt wait every day to put in some time. This is a great book, not political, and time travel told very well. HIGHLY recommended as a different type of read.

This is the very first book by Stephen King that I have read.  I have always been turned off by his horror type books/movies.  I ordered it without realizing who the arthor was upon the reccommendation from GMA one morning.  The book is really great.  It pulls you into the time and holds you to the story and you can't let go.  Since finishing the book I passed it on to 3 other people who do not read his books.  They loved it too.

I've been a King fan for 30 years and I can honestly say this is one of his all time best.  As usual, I couldn't put it down but not just because I was curious how it ended.  I actually felt what the characters were feeling and I was scared for them too. Takes a lot for me to get that connected to a story, but Stephen did it again.  Just started reading his son's works too.  Joe Hill has some great stuff our there.  Apple/Tree...

I never read Steven King novels but this book is very different. He combines a good story with history. It is not horror fiction but can make you think!! I am impressed with his writing ability and was immediately drawn into the story. Don't be put off by its length. I could not put it down. It is not intended to prove or disprove a conspirator theory but tells a good story about what could happen if history could be changed..

Excellent book - it stays with you. It was probably longer than it needed to be, but the pages flew - I couldn't wait to get to the end and then was sorry I had, not that there was anything wrong with the end, I would just miss the adventure! I thought about the premise and refleced on my own life and how it would turn if I had the same opportunity as the protagonist. Intriguing. A good read and great adventure. Well written.

This is a romance wrapped in time travel wrapped in the events surrounding the assassination of JFK. Funny enough, even though King is not known for romance or sex scenes, here this is the most riveting part of the book. The Oswald stuff tends to get a little boring but bearable. I found it overall to be sweet and sensitive while interesting, a feat since I am not of an age to have been alive yet when these events occurred.

I really can't say more than what has already been said, so I'll keep it simple.  This book is amazing, will keep you reading well into the night, has some thrills, and plenty of heart.  If you have ever liked SK, you will like this book.  If you have never read SK, then this is a good one to start with.  This is one of those books that you hate to finish, but can't stop reading until it's over.  Bravo, Mr. King, Bravo.

Can't really say much more than so many other reviewers, but I couldn't put this book down.  It was exciting, unexpected, with twists and turns I didn't see coming.  Loved the alternate universe/ post-apocalpytic section and particularly his very interesting view of how would-be politicians would have made decisions!  This is certainly an exciting and wonderful read - just had a hard time holding the book up in bed!

I am currently suffering from a spine condition, and for the first time in my professional life am unable to work. This book is so engaging that it is rescuing me from near-depression. You can really lose yourself in this story; it is pure genius. After I finish this, I will probably catch up on other books by him that I have missed. This is truly the definitive "great read". Thank you, Mr. King, for the rescue.

I really enjoyed this book. Time travel, political assassination, space-time continuum, The Butterfly Effect, vigilanty justice, a love story and more rolled into a very entertaining and thought provoking 850 page read. The Kennedy Assassination is one of my first memories and I have been intrigued with time travel since watching the 60's fantasy TV show "Time Tunnel" as a kid. Fun ride that I hated to see end.

I thoroughly enjoyed this book. I had never read a novel by Stephen King before, but this is a great place to start. When I read, I need to get sucked in by the story, the characters, or some other basic aspect of the book. The premise of this book was intriguing to me and King makes a very unusual plot line work. I loved this book, and, like any good book, I was a bit sad when it was over. Very, very good.

Great story telling as usual. I am thankful King hasnt lost the ability to knit a new thread of existence with his storytelling. Sometimes I even wonder if he isnt just looking through some glass at alternate realities and writes what he observes. I am not a history nut at all, and general things that tend towards the nonfiction bore me, but this novel kept me reading long past when i called it a night.

11/22/63 is easily King's best work of recent years.  The amount of research done, from the events of the Kennedy assassination to the price of a root beer float in 1958, is quite impressive.  The characters are well conceived, and while the idea of time travel and stopping the Kennedy assassination has been done, 11/22/63 is one of the most compelling and thoughtful of them.  Absolutely recommended.

I got this book for my dad for Christmas, because he's such a history buff and very much a Kennedy fan. He really enjoyed it. I read it after he finished and I was amazed at the story-telling that King presents. He's quite a talented and detailed writer. This was the first King book I've ever read, and I was thoroughly amazed by it. It is intense, sad, gripping, and terrifying all at the same time.

I was so looking forward to this book since I hadn't read a Stephen King novel in years and the premise sounded exciting.  My expectations were heightened by a good review in the NY Times.  I put forth a valiant effort to finish it because I truly wanted to find out if George/Jake was able to stop JFK's assassination, but I read only 291 of the 800+ pages before I reluctantly gave up.  The time-travel story was very good and I admire the scope of the project, but I just couldn't get past the writing (my apologies to Stephen King and all his fans --- I used to be one myself).  Even though I read nearly 300 pages, I still didn't have a handle on even the main character.  The dialogue seemed artificial and stilted and no one "came alive" for me.  I just couldn't see myself slogging through the final 500+ pages.  So many books, so little time.

I don't even know where to begin. I believe the time and energy King spent in creating this novel was exhaustive. I refuse to even use the word "write". Anybody can write. It takes an artist to create. I have my own opinions on the JFK assassination, but after reading this book, I am inclined to research further. This novel was brilliant and I will be reading it again in the future.

This might be one of my favorite Stephen King novels.  Living in Dallas, I especially enjoyed the references to familiar places.  I also like his novels that are not as far fetched as cars that drive themselves or killer clowns that come up out of sewer drains.  Time travel may be fantasy, but the story is told in such a way that it becomes believable.  And isn't that what good writing is?

11-22-63 had me hooked in the beginning, got a bit long in the middle, and pulled me back in the end. Stephen King has a way of making you think, that I haven't found with other authors. This is an excellent novel. It's a pretty cool story that isn't so much about dissecting the Kennedy assassination as the title might make you believe. It's much more. Do yourself a favor. Read this book.

This is the best of King's novels that I have read in a long time, set in a time period that I identify with. It was just the right mixture of nostalgia, suspense, atmosphere, and plot to keep me reading toward the end, hoping at the same time that it wouldn't end. Ordering from Amazon is a breeze, giving me immediate and affordable access to the best and latest from my favorite authors.

Got this book for Christmas and I loved it. I read the first chapter when it first came out and i was hooked so when i got it some months later i was excited. As a fan of American history this book was right up my alley. the thought of time travel to change history was fascinating to me. In ending this book is a page turner and i hated for it to end. it was well worth the 849 pages!

If you like sci-fi novels you will like this. Most of book is set in the 50's and 60's and how life is in that time period. This book is mostly a historic novel but the sci-fi feel and element is there througgt out the book. I can't speak for everyone but if you like history and sci-fi and good story's about changing the past and the trials that go with it. Then its worth reading

What a pleasure!  I am just into the first third of the book and can already tell it is one of Stephen King's usual top notch thrillers.  It is such a joy any time I get a new King novel, and this is going to be no exception.  When figuring in cost, shipping and time of delivery, one can really appreciate this being a wonderful bargain and delightful read.  Thank you Amazon, you have come through again!

Like many, I'm a huge Stephen King fan. I enjoyed the book, although I wouldn't rate it as one of my top five King reads. I noticed I didn't quite read the with usual fast page turning pace that I usually do with one of his works. Nevertheless, I enjoyed picking it up every night, anxiously awaiting the moment when the main character would eventually makes it to 11/22/63.

I'm a very long time reader and fan of Stephen King.  I consider "11/22/63" to be yet another in a generally reliable string of great stories from "the Master" -- it is not King's very best work but it is likewise very far from what I consider to be his worst work.  I give it a good solid B+ and would certainly recommend it to other King fans (and have done so!).

Thank you Mr. King for writing 11.23.63.  The research for this book must have been incredible.  It is easy to suspend disbelief while following Jake through his journey.  It has prompted me to research that dreadful day and the people involved.  Like so many of Mr. Kings's other stories, the writing is well done and the story well crafted.  This book has a permanent place on my bookshelf.

I have never cared much for the horror genre.  So it is surprising I have read a great deal of Stephen Kings books.  Why?  Because he is a master story teller.  Not since his book "It" have I enjoyed one of his works so much as this one.  Here I get the master story teller in a science fiction novel rather than his comfort zone.  I could not put this book down!

I do believe that some of the reviewers here need to lighten up a bit. This book is what it is: a good story. Also a fun read. It kept my interest and got me thinking about the nature of history and to what extent our actions can effect it. If one isn't able to suspend judgement to immerse oneself in something, what's the point? That's what life is all about.

I looked forward to reading this book. I liked the idea it held onto reality with the idea of cause and effect - for ever action there is a reaction. That the energy of the universe is bound and if changed will re-route its course -- and watch out as energy if it's dramatic and devastating can only be the same again. I thought this book is well worth reading.

Just finished reading book, and I am very pleased.  he keeps the writing simple, and poignant.  People have complained about his apparent lack of editing (for length), but I only wish he would have kept writing more.  I found myself caught up with "George's" adventures back in time.  For lovers of King, you will also find subtle connections to his other work.

This book was the featured book for my monthly Book Club, and we all really enjoyed it. It is a very long book (and also heavy to carry around), but the storyline is great and I was sucked in after about 4 or 5 pages. I would say that the beginning was a tad slow, but I couldn't put it down after a while. Stephen King books never fail to keep me coming back.

I enjoyed the characters, but the protagonist's motivation for taking on the "mission" is questionable and the ending was a bit hokey. Preferred Under the Dome. Although, like Dome, this one was also too long. (I should also add I wasn't born until the 70s and don't have the same feelings and recollections of the previous era as those alive then might have.)

This is the first Stephen King book I have read in over 20 years and I am not sure why I waited so long.........This book is great. I have read at least a dozen of his books back when I was in High School/ College. 11/22/63 has all of Stephen King's twisted passions and talents......and great fun with time travel and "butterfly effect". Do not miss this one.

I often don't get this fired up about a book I've read. 11/22/63 by Stephen King. If you lived through the early 60's and remember where you were when you heard that JFK had been shot, this book will give you a powerful punch. If you did not, and love reading a master, you will be enthralled. 11/22/63 sets a new standard for top-quality mainstream fiction.

Time travel is great to think about but the care taken to examine Lee Harvey Oswald was profound.  This book comes close to The Stand which in my estimation is one of the greatest books Mr. King has ever written.. I love how he takes the time to finish the book. Sometimes writers have problems ending a huge book as this but not this time.. My compliments.

Absolutely amazing. I have not enjoyed a book as much as I enjoyed this one in a really long time. It's a page turner-almost 900 pages and I finished it in a matter of days. I was so enthralled by this novel, that I was exhausted at work due to my late nights reading. Horrible title, but I have recommended 11/22/63 to absolutely everyone I know. Enjoy.

Once again Kng demonstrates his skills and writing, bothin the story line development, the descriptive writing and the flow.  It certainlyh is not a horror book by any stretch of the imagination, but a wondrful listen (audio book).  the reader was great.  My wife and I enjoyed this for the 30 plus hours and felt it was time well spent.  A quality work.

11-22-63 is a time travel story without the physics and threat of temporal anomalies that are prevalent in science fiction novels.  Stephen King tells a terrific story of ordinary people in extraordinary circumstances.  His attention to the historic details of real people, places and events makes 11-22-63 a treat to read, especially for those us old enough to remember them.
Very different from any Stephen King book I've read before and there have been a lot... Such an interesting premise. I guess it could be considered historical fiction. You'll like it.

I pretty much read everything by King, so I didn't really research this book before purchasing. I thought it was going to be more of a research/factual book about the assassination. I was pleasantly surprised when I discovered it was about time travel and trying to change the past. I have often daydreamed about being able to go back and stop Hitler and how that would change history. I think all King fans and most other readers will enjoy this book.
my first Stephen king book. loved it,
The book was riveting, and probably the most informative work I have read. Stephen king is my favorite writer, and I would love it if it baca me a movie.

I started this journey months ago and King's writing has been a great comfort to long train rides and lunch hours. I enjoy his writing style and ability to tell fascinating stories with great imagination and detail. The love story component and the idea of living in the past in order to right an American tragedy was a perfect setting to King's prose and intense attention to detail. I believe this book was a labor of love and it was beautifully executed.

Wonderful novel! I write time travel fiction, and I'm a stickler when it comes to finding time travel conundrums and poorly executed plot twists. Imagine my delight as I delved into Stephen King's smart, well-written, fast-paced, and heartfelt romantic adventure! And Mr. King, if you ever read this, I want you to know your son was right - the ending is perfect. I will keep this book on my shelf and read it again. It's that good.
My first Stephen King novel. Impossible to put down. I am usually a fast reader but not with this one. I wanted to savor every last word.

The attention to detail is incredible. I did not want to read this originally as I do not care for politics or conspiracy theories. This was not at all what I expected. It was a beautiful love story, meticulously researched historical fiction and addresses other issues of was the past simpler. Very creative tie back to Derry, king has proven he can master any kind of writing he puts his mind to.
I have read every Stephen King novel ever written....some I like more than others.  This book was fresh and I was completely engaged from the word "The".  King can spin a yarn like no one living.
Hard to put this one down. Really like how story intertwines with actual events.  I am from Dallas so interesting to here about familiar surroundings and at an earlier time than my time.

This isn't typical reading. it takes you on a journey...several of them actually. You can't out guess it, it will surprise you every time. The master has exceeded expectations. Kennedy's death is a time I share with many. High school...well remembered. Old Yoopers will love this book, I did.
Great book by the master Stephen King!!!! This has motion picture written all over it. The twists and turns are all classic King.
Omg I loved this book so much and I'm so sad to be done with it!  Lol. It was such an easy and fun read!

It doesn't matter what age you are, but if you lived through the 60's, you won't believe what's in store!  Master King does it again!!!!  A true masterpiece and so thought provoking!  Brings on every emotion inside you!  As with many of his others, especially Duma Key, I hated for it to end!!!
Really enjoyed reading this tale from start to finish. I will definitely continue to check out more of King's works in the future.

I absolutely loved it!! Not a typical Stephen King novel. It kept me guessing about the outcome of something that occurred in history!  Superb writing!! It provoked thought about our every action. A book that made me sad when it came to an end.

For all who remember the Kennedy assassination, for all Stephen King fans, for all who love his incredible ability to evoke an era, an atmosphere, a love affair, a ghost, a monster and a beautiful girl, this book is a total gift! Loved it and miss it already!

Was intrigued by the book cover and curious to see where Stephen King would go with this premise. For over 1100 pages he held my interest and kept my pulse racing.  Won't risk spoilers, but his ending is a twist I didn't see coming, and I've been enthralled by his work since Carrie's prom night.  His characters are three-dimensional, his narrative atmospheric and compelling as always.  Worth the time to follow him back to 11/22/63 and find out what happened - really.

Amazon sent me a note saying I had not reviewed this book.  Obviously that means my voice is needed, as 6,000+ positive reviews is not near enough.  Well, here is the final word so Amazon can feel they have done their best to persuade me to speak:  I AGREE!  This is a great book!
I never even thought about how long it was. The story was so captivating!  Would love to see on screen! May read it again soon.
The premise was very thought provoking.  Not the typical Stephen King thriller but very enjoyable reading.  The end is worth it.

Not since"The Stand" have I read a book of this quality coming from Stephen King.  There have been other books dealing with time travel,  which has been a fantasy of mine since childhood,  but they've all been silly and disappointing,  until now. Bravo,  Mr. King.
One of the best books I have ever read.  Never got dull or boring and kept me interested from the beginning to the end.
It was a nice, easy to get lost in story.  It was the perfect book to read after finals.  Just don't expect too much from the plot.
Good story and a look back at history in the 1960s.  Our book club loved it, and found many topics for discussion.
Good book as usual.  Stephen King books are always good.  Not one of his bests, but still good.  I would recommend it.

This is a well written, well researched, thought provoking look at time travel and the potential consequences to reality.  The information researched about Lee Harvey Oswald's life leading up to the assassination of Kennedy makes a great backdrop for playing with time travel.  Kennedy's assassination is one of those pivotal moments that people pick in a discussion over time travel and changing the past.  The main character was engaging and the narrative kept me wondering where exactly King was going.  The end was satisfying and not totally predictable.

I had to read this for a book club and was not thrilled, especially over the length of it. I thought it might be the usual Stephen King horror story, but was surprised to find myself pulled in and enjoying it. What a great imagination King has.  The discussion at the club meeting proved lively and thoughtful. I found the ending of the book to be satisfying. This book really makes one think about what would have happened had JFK lived.
from the master of horror comes still yet another book that will make your mind wonder every minnute from begin to the end.
The ending was not was I was expecting. Kind of went weird at the end. All in all, it did keep me turning pages.

I enjoy SK books. This a bit too long but it is the original King style. I think you could red it twice and pick new things up with each read. I did think there were too mny years involved so that would be my only complaint. It is very well researchrd though. To all SK fans it is a good read. Enjoy!!
King's recent novels just get better and better. 11/22/63 is not only excellent writing but also very thought provoking. "What would have happened if . . ."

I had this on my Kindle for a long time before I read it and I'm sorry I waited so long. This is not a horror story and I am recommending it to everyone especially to people who do not usually read books by Stephen King. This will appeal to anyone who remembers the day Kennedy as assassinated and thinks "if only". It has such wonderful character development that I am still thinking about the main characters and missing them and it has ben a long time since a book has affected me that way.
Stephan King almost always delivers and I think he really did a fantastic job with this approach to time travel.

The idea of preventing Kennedy's assination is fascinating.  King's writing was descriptive and his characters well developed.  The extensive research was obvious.  I do think that the book was is long but otherwise I enjoyed it.

This book is an exciting read. It mixes history with and fiction, in a new and interesting way. King always develops his characters so they really seem real and quirky. It is a page turner because you really get caught up in the drama, even if we know all the end of the story. it is interesting how he gets us back to reality. That is why I am a Stephen King fan.
This is great Steven King.  Keeps you in suspense the whole time and weaves a very interesting story.  Hard to put down once you start reading.
